{"uri": "8160991559", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "11:23:04", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T11:23:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T11:22:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.wptv.com/world/israel-at-war/us-urges-un-security-council-to-support-cease-fire-plan-in-gaza-announced-by-biden", "title": "US urges UN Security Council to support cease-fire plan in Gaza announced by Biden", "body": "People speak during a Security Council meeting about the war in Gaza at United Nations headquarters, Wednesday, May 29, 2024.\n\nThe U.S. urged the U.N. Security Council on Monday to support the three-phase plan announced by President Joe Biden aimed at ending the nearly eight-month war in Gaza, freeing all hostages and sending massive aid into the devastated territory.\n\nU.S. Ambassador Linda Thomas-Greenfield said the United States circulated a draft resolution to the 14 other council members to back the proposal for ending the conflict that began with Hamas' surprise attack in southern Israel on Oct. 7 that killed some 1,200 people, mostly Israeli civilians.\n\n\"Numerous leaders and governments, including in the region, have endorsed this plan and we call on the Security Council to join them in calling for implementation of this deal without delay and without further conditions,\" she said in a statement.\n\nThe brief draft resolution, obtained by The Associated Press, would welcome the May 31 deal announced by President Biden and call on Hamas \"to accept it fully and implement its terms without delay and without condition.\" Hamas has said it views the proposal \"positively.\"\n\nIt makes no mention of Israeli acceptance of the deal.\n\nWhen President Biden made the announcement, he called it an Israeli offer that includes an \"enduring cease-fire\" and Israeli withdrawal from Gaza if Hamas releases all hostages it is holding.\n\nIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu told his hardline governing partners Monday the proposal announced by President Biden would meet Israel's goal of destroying Hamas, according to local media. The ultranationalists have threatened to bring down his government if Netanyahu agrees to a deal that doesn't eliminate Hamas.\n\nNetanyahu told parliament's Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee on Monday that President Biden gave an outline of the deal but not all the details, and he said there are \"gaps.\"\n\nPresident Biden said the first phase of the proposed deal would last for six weeks and include a \"full and complete cease-fire,\" a withdrawal of Israeli forces from all populated areas of Gaza and the release of some hostages, including women, the elderly and the wounded, in exchange for the release of hundreds of Palestinian prisoners.\n\nIsrael at War\n\nIsrael declares 4 more hostages are dead in Gaza, including 3 older men AP via Scripps News 5:29 PM, Jun 03, 2024\n\nAmerican hostages would be released at this stage, and remains of hostages who have been killed would be returned to their families. There would be a surge in humanitarian assistance, with 600 trucks a day entering Gaza.\n\nIn the second phase, all the rest of the living hostages would be released, including soldiers, and Israeli forces would withdraw from Gaza. President Biden said if Hamas lives up to its commitments, the temporary cease-fire would become a \"cessation of hostilities permanently.\"\n\nAbout 250 people, mainly Israeli civilians, were abducted on Oct. 7, then more than 100 were freed in a short truce in late November and early December. Israel says about 80 hostages are believed to still be captive, alongside the remains of about 43 others.\n\nIsraeli bombardments and ground offensives in Gaza, which Hamas has ruled, have killed more than 36,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry, which does not distinguish between combatants and civilians.\n\nThe third phase of the plan announced by President Biden calls for the start of a major reconstruction of Gaza, which faces decades of rebuilding from devastation caused by the war.\n\nThe draft resolution stresses the importance of Israel and Hamas adhering to the deal once it is agreed to, \"with the aim of bringing about a permanent cessation of hostilities, and calls upon all member states and the United Nations to support its implementation.\"\n\nThe draft would also reiterate the council's \"unwavering commitment\" to a two-state solution, and stress the importance of unifying the Gaza Strip and the West Bank under the Palestinian Authority.\n\nThomas-Greenfield, the U.S. ambassador, said Security Council members \"have consistently called for the steps outlined in this deal: bringing the hostages home, ensuring a complete ceasefire, enabling a surge of humanitarian assistance into Gaza and in the refurbishment of essential services, and setting the stage for a long-term reconstruction plan for Gaza.\"\n\n\"Council members should not let this opportunity pass by,\" she said. \"We must speak with one voice in support of this deal.\"\n\nOn Monday, the foreign ministers of five key Arab nations -- Jordan, the United Arab Emirates, Saudi Arabia, Qatar and Egypt -- urged Israel and Hamas to consider President Biden's proposal \"seriously and positively.\"\n\nThe group of seven major industrialized nations -- the U.S., Britain, France, Germany, Japan, Canada and Italy -- also backed the cease-fire plan.", "source": {"uri": "wptv.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WPTV"}, "authors": [], "concepts": Security Council to Support Biden's Ceasefire Proposal", "body": "UNITED NATIONS -- The United States urged the U.N. Security Council on Monday to support the three-phase plan announced by President Joe Biden aimed at ending the nearly eight-month war in Gaza, freeing all hostages and sending massive aid into the devastated territory.\n\nU.S. Ambassador Linda Thomas-Greenfield said the United States circulated a draft resolution to the 14 other council members to back the proposal for ending the conflict that began with Hamas' surprise attack in southern Israel on Oct. 7 that killed some 1,200 people, mostly Israeli civilians.\n\n\"Numerous leaders and governments, including in the region, have endorsed this plan and we call on the Security Council to join them in calling for implementation of this deal without delay and without further conditions,\" she said in a statement.\n\nRead More: Americans Used to Care More About Israel Dividing the U.S. From Its U.N. Allies\n\nThe brief draft resolution, obtained by The Associated Press, would welcome the May 31 deal announced by Biden and call on Hamas \"to accept it fully and implement its terms without delay and without condition.\" Hamas has said it views the proposal \"positively.\"\n\nIt makes no mention of Israeli acceptance of the deal.\n\nWhen Biden made the announcement he called it an Israeli offer that includes an \"enduring ceasefire\" and Israeli withdrawal from Gaza if Hamas releases all hostages it is holding.\n\nIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu told his hardline governing partners Monday the proposal announced by Biden would meet Israel's goal of destroying Hamas, according to local media. The ultranationalists have threatened to bring down his government if Netanyahu agrees to a deal that doesn't eliminate Hamas.\n\nNetanyahu told parliament's Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee on Monday that Biden gave an outline of the deal but not all the details, and he said there are \"gaps.\"\n\nRead More: It's Time for Netanyahu to Complete the Israel-Hamas Deal and Take the Loss\n\nBiden said the first phase of the proposed deal would last for six weeks and include a \"full and complete ceasefire,\" a withdrawal of Israeli forces from all populated areas of Gaza and the release of some hostages, including women, the elderly and the wounded, in exchange for the release of hundreds of Palestinian prisoners.\n\nAmerican hostages would be released at this stage, and remains of hostages who have been killed would be returned to their families. There would be a surge in humanitarian assistance, with 600 trucks a day entering Gaza.\n\nIn the second phase, all the rest of the living hostages would be released, including soldiers, and Israeli forces would withdraw from Gaza. Biden said if Hamas lives up to its commitments, the temporary ceasefire would become a \"cessation of hostilities permanently.\"\n\nAbout 250 people, mainly Israeli civilians, were abducted on Oct. 7, then more than 100 were freed in a short truce in late November and early December. Israel says about 80 hostages are believed to still be captive, alongside the remains of about 43 others.\n\nIsraeli bombardments and ground offensives in Gaza, which Hamas has ruled, have killed more than 36,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry, which does not distinguish between combatants and civilians.\n\nRead More: The Science Is Clear. Over 30,000 People Have Died in Gaza\n\nThe third phase of the plan announced by Biden calls for the start of a major reconstruction of Gaza, which faces decades of rebuilding from devastation caused by the war.\n\nThe draft resolution stresses the importance of Israel and Hamas adhering to the deal once it is agreed to, \"with the aim of bringing about a permanent cessation of hostilities, and calls upon all member states and the United Nations to support its implementation.\"\n\nThe draft would also reiterate the council's \"unwavering commitment\" to a two-state solution, and stress the importance of unifying the Gaza Strip and the West Bank under the Palestinian Authority.\n\nThomas-Greenfield, the U.S. ambassador, said Security Council members \"have consistently called for the steps outlined in this deal: bringing the hostages home, ensuring a complete ceasefire, enabling a surge of humanitarian assistance into Gaza and in the refurbishment of essential services, and setting the stage for a long-term reconstruction plan for Gaza.\"\n\n\"Council members should not let this opportunity pass by,\" she said. \"We must speak with one voice in support of this deal.\"\n\nOn Monday, the foreign ministers of five key Arab nations -- Jordan, the United Arab Emirates, Saudi Arabia, Qatar and Egypt -- urged Israel and Hamas to consider Biden's proposal \"seriously and positively.\"\n\nThe group of seven major industrialized nations -- the U.S., Britain, France, Germany, Japan, Canada and Italy -- also backed the ceasefire plan.", "source": {"uri": "time.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "TIME"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@time.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": true}, {"uri": "edith_m_lederer@time.com", "name": "Edith M. {"uri": "2024-06-378073419", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "07:58:13", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T07:58:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T04:28:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://tribtown.com/2024/06/04/us-urges-un-security-council-to-support-cease-fire-plan-in-gaza-announced-by-president-biden/", "title": "US urges UN Security Council to support cease-fire plan in Gaza announced by President Biden", "body": "UNITED NATIONS (AP) -- The United States urged the U.N. Security Council on Monday to support the three-phase plan announced by President Joe Biden aimed at ending the nearly eight-month war in Gaza, freeing all hostages and sending massive aid into the devastated territory.\n\nU.S. Ambassador Linda Thomas-Greenfield said the United States circulated a draft resolution to the 14 other council members to back the proposal for ending the conflict that began with Hamas' surprise attack in southern Israel on Oct. 7 that killed some 1,200 people, mostly Israeli civilians.\n\n\"Numerous leaders and governments, including in the region, have endorsed this plan and we call on the Security Council to join them in calling for implementation of this deal without delay and without further conditions,\" she said in a statement.\n\nThe brief draft resolution, obtained by The Associated Press, would welcome the May 31 deal announced by Biden and call on Hamas \"to accept it fully and implement its terms without delay and without condition.\" Hamas has said it views the proposal \"positively.\"\n\nIt makes no mention of Israeli acceptance of the deal.\n\nWhen Biden made the announcement he called it an Israeli offer that includes an \"enduring cease-fire\" and Israeli withdrawal from Gaza if Hamas releases all hostages it is holding.\n\nIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu told his hardline governing partners Monday the proposal announced by Biden would meet Israel's goal of destroying Hamas, according to local media. The ultranationalists have threatened to bring down his government if Netanyahu agrees to a deal that doesn't eliminate Hamas.\n\nNetanyahu told parliament's Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee on Monday that Biden gave an outline of the deal but not all the details, and he said there are \"gaps.\"\n\nBiden said the first phase of the proposed deal would last for six weeks and include a \"full and complete cease-fire,\" a withdrawal of Israeli forces from all populated areas of Gaza and the release of some hostages, including women, the elderly and the wounded, in exchange for the release of hundreds of Palestinian prisoners.\n\nAmerican hostages would be released at this stage, and remains of hostages who have been killed would be returned to their families. There would be a surge in humanitarian assistance, with 600 trucks a day entering Gaza.\n\nIn the second phase, all the rest of the living hostages would be released, including soldiers, and Israeli forces would withdraw from Gaza. Biden said if Hamas lives up to its commitments, the temporary cease-fire would become a \"cessation of hostilities permanently.\"\n\nAbout 250 people, mainly Israeli civilians, were abducted on Oct. 7, then more than 100 were freed in a short truce in late November and early December. Israel says about 80 hostages are believed to still be captive, alongside the remains of about 43 others.\n\nIsraeli bombardments and ground offensives in Gaza, which Hamas has ruled, have killed more than 36,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry, which does not distinguish between combatants and civilians.\n\nThe third phase of the plan announced by Biden calls for the start of a major reconstruction of Gaza, which faces decades of rebuilding from devastation caused by the war.\n\nThe draft resolution stresses the importance of Israel and Hamas adhering to the deal once it is agreed to, \"with the aim of bringing about a permanent cessation of hostilities, and calls upon all member states and the United Nations to support its implementation.\"\n\nThe draft would also reiterate the council's \"unwavering commitment\" to a two-state solution, and stress the importance of unifying the Gaza Strip and the West Bank under the Palestinian Authority.\n\nThomas-Greenfield, the U.S. ambassador, said Security Council members \"have consistently called for the steps outlined in this deal: bringing the hostages home, ensuring a complete ceasefire, enabling a surge of humanitarian assistance into Gaza and in the refurbishment of essential services, and setting the stage for a long-term reconstruction plan for Gaza.\"\n\n\"Council members should not let this opportunity pass by,\" she said. \"We must speak with one voice in support of this deal.\"\n\nOn Monday, the foreign ministers of five key Arab nations -- Jordan, the United Arab Emirates, Saudi Arabia, Qatar and Egypt -- urged Israel and Hamas to consider Biden's proposal \"seriously and positively.\"\n\nThe group of seven major industrialized nations -- the U.S., Britain, France, Germany, Japan, Canada and Italy -- also backed the cease-fire plan.", "source": {"uri": "tribtown.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@tribtown.com", The ultranationalists have threatened to bring down his government if Netanyahu agrees to a deal that doesn't eliminate Hamas.\n\nNetanyahu told parliament's Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee on Monday that Biden gave an outline of the deal but not all the details, and he said there are \"gaps.\"\n\nBiden said the first phase of the proposed deal would last for six weeks and include a \"full and complete cease-fire,\" a withdrawal of Israeli forces from all populated areas of Gaza and the release of some hostages, including women, the elderly and the wounded, in exchange for the release of hundreds of Palestinian prisoners.\n\nAmerican hostages would be released at this stage, and remains of hostages who have been killed would be returned to their families. There would be a surge in humanitarian assistance, with 600 trucks a day entering Gaza.\n\nIn the second phase, all the rest of the living hostages would be released, including soldiers, and Israeli forces would withdraw from Gaza. Biden said if Hamas lives up to its commitments, the temporary cease-fire would become a \"cessation of hostilities permanently.\"\n\nAbout 250 people, mainly Israeli civilians, were abducted on Oct. 7, then more than 100 were freed in a short truce in late November and early December. Israel says about 80 hostages are believed to still be captive, alongside the remains of about 43 others.\n\nIsraeli bombardments and ground offensives in Gaza, which Hamas has ruled, have killed more than 36,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry, which does not distinguish between combatants and civilians.\n\nThe third phase of the plan announced by Biden calls for the start of a major reconstruction of Gaza, which faces decades of rebuilding from devastation caused by the war.\n\nThe draft resolution stresses the importance of Israel and Hamas adhering to the deal once it is agreed to, \"with the aim of bringing about a permanent cessation of hostilities, and calls upon all member states and the United Nations to support its implementation.\"\n\nThe draft would also {"uri": "8160413472", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "04:52:32", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T04:52:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T04:50:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13491821/US-urges-UN-Security-Council-support-cease-fire-plan-Gaza-announced-President-Biden.html", "title": "US urges UN Security Council to support cease-fire plan in Gaza...", "body": "UNITED NATIONS (AP) - The United States urged the U.N. Security Council on Monday to support the three-phase plan announced by President Joe Biden aimed at ending the nearly eight-month war in Gaza, freeing all hostages and sending massive aid into the devastated territory.\n\nU.S. Ambassador Linda Thomas-Greenfield said the United States circulated a draft resolution to the 14 other council members to back the proposal for ending the conflict that began with Hamas\u00b4 surprise attack in southern Israel on Oct. 7 that killed some 1,200 people, mostly Israeli civilians.\n\n\"Numerous leaders and governments, including in the region, have endorsed this plan and we call on the Security Council to join them in calling for implementation of this deal without delay and without further conditions,\" she said in a statement.\n\nThe brief draft resolution, obtained by The Associated Press, would welcome the May 31 deal announced by Biden and call on Hamas \"to accept it fully and implement its terms without delay and without condition.\" Hamas has said it views the proposal \"positively.\"\n\nIt makes no mention of Israeli acceptance of the deal.\n\nWhen Biden made the announcement he called it an Israeli offer that includes an \"enduring cease-fire\" and Israeli withdrawal from Gaza if Hamas releases all hostages it is holding.\n\nPeople speak during a Security Council meeting about the war in Gaza at United Nations headquarters, Wednesday, May 29, 2024. (AP Photo/Seth Wenig)\n\nIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu told his hardline governing partners Monday the proposal announced by Biden would meet Israel\u00b4s goal of destroying Hamas, according to local media. The ultranationalists have threatened to bring down his government if Netanyahu agrees to a deal that doesn\u00b4t eliminate Hamas.\n\nNetanyahu told parliament\u00b4s Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee on Monday that Biden gave an outline of the deal but not all the details, and he said there are \"gaps.\"\n\nBiden said the first phase of the proposed deal would last for six weeks and include a \"full and complete cease-fire,\" a withdrawal of Israeli forces from all populated areas of Gaza and the release of some hostages, including women, the elderly and the wounded, in exchange for the release of hundreds of Palestinian prisoners.\n\nAmerican hostages would be released at this stage, and remains of hostages who have been killed would be returned to their families. There would be a surge in humanitarian assistance, with 600 trucks a day entering Gaza.\n\nIn the second phase, all the rest of the living hostages would be released, including soldiers, and Israeli forces would withdraw from Gaza. Biden said if Hamas lives up to its commitments, the temporary cease-fire would become a \"cessation of hostilities permanently.\"\n\nAbout 250 people, mainly Israeli civilians, were abducted on Oct. 7, then more than 100 were freed in a short truce in late November and early December. Israel says about 80 hostages are believed to still be captive, alongside the remains of about 43 others.\n\nIsraeli bombardments and ground offensives in Gaza, which Hamas has ruled, have killed more than 36,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza\u00b4s Health Ministry, which does not distinguish between combatants and civilians.\n\nThe third phase of the plan announced by Biden calls for the start of a major reconstruction of Gaza, which faces decades of rebuilding from devastation caused by the war.\n\nThe draft resolution stresses the importance of Israel and Hamas adhering to the deal once it is agreed to, \"with the aim of bringing about a permanent cessation of hostilities, and calls upon all member states and the United Nations to support its implementation.\"\n\nThe draft would also reiterate the council\u00b4s \"unwavering commitment\" to a two-state solution, and stress the importance of unifying the Gaza Strip and the West Bank under the Palestinian Authority.\n\nThomas-Greenfield, the U.S. ambassador, said Security Council members \"have consistently called for the steps outlined in this deal: bringing the hostages home, ensuring a complete ceasefire, enabling a surge of humanitarian assistance into Gaza and in the refurbishment of essential services, and setting the stage for a long-term reconstruction plan for Gaza.\"\n\n\"Council members should not let this opportunity pass by,\" she said. \"We must speak with one voice in support of this deal.\"\n\nOn Monday, the foreign ministers of five key Arab nations - Jordan, the United Arab Emirates, Saudi Arabia, Qatar and Egypt - urged Israel and Hamas to consider Biden\u00b4s proposal \"seriously and positively.\"\n\nThe group of seven major industrialized nations - the U.S., Britain, France, Germany, Japan, Canada and Italy - also backed the cease-fire plan.", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, "authors": [], The ultranationalists have threatened to bring down his government if Netanyahu agrees to a deal that does not eliminate Hamas.\n\nNetanyahu told the Israeli parliament's Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee yesterday that Biden gave an outline of the deal but not all the details and he said there are \"gaps\".\n\nThe US president said the first phase of the proposed deal would last for six weeks and include a \"full and complete ceasefire,\" a withdrawal of Israeli forces from all populated areas of Gaza and the release of some hostages, including women, the elderly and the wounded, in exchange for the release of hundreds of Palestinian prisoners.\n\nAmerican hostages would be released at this stage and remains of hostages who have been killed would be returned to their families. Israel says about 80 hostages are believed to still be captive, alongside the remains of about 43 others.\n\nIsraeli bombardments and ground offensives in Gaza have killed more than 36,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry.\n\nThe third phase of the plan announced by Biden calls for the start of a major reconstruction of Gaza, which faces decades of rebuilding from hostilities, and calls upon all member states and the United Nations to support its implementation.\"\n\nThe draft would also reiterate the council's \"unwavering commitment\" to a two-state solution {"uri": "2024-06-377902273", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "04:43:20", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T04:43:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T00:28:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/us/articles/2024-06-04/us-urges-un-security-council-to-support-cease-fire-plan-in-gaza-announced-by-president-biden", "title": "US Urges UN Security Council to Support Cease-Fire Plan in Gaza Announced by President Biden", "body": "UNITED NATIONS (AP) -- The United States urged the U.N. Security Council on Monday to support the three-phase plan announced by President Joe Biden aimed at ending the nearly eight-month war in Gaza, freeing all hostages and sending massive aid into the devastated territory.\n\nU.S. Ambassador Linda Thomas-Greenfield said the United States circulated a draft resolution to the 14 other council members to back the proposal for ending the conflict that began with Hamas' surprise attack in southern Israel on Oct. 7 that killed some 1,200 people, mostly Israeli civilians.\n\n\"Numerous leaders and governments, including in the region, have endorsed this plan and we call on the Security Council to join them in calling for implementation of this deal without delay and without further conditions,\" she said in a statement.\n\nThe brief draft resolution, obtained by The Associated Press, would welcome the May 31 deal announced by Biden and call on Hamas \"to accept it fully and implement its terms without delay and without condition.\" Hamas has said it views the proposal \"positively.\"\n\nIt makes no mention of Israeli acceptance of the deal.\n\nWhen Biden made the announcement he called it an Israeli offer that includes an \"enduring cease-fire\" and Israeli withdrawal from Gaza if Hamas releases all hostages it is holding.\n\nIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu told his hardline governing partners Monday the proposal announced by Biden would meet Israel's goal of destroying Hamas, according to local media. The ultranationalists have threatened to bring down his government if Netanyahu agrees to a deal that doesn't eliminate Hamas.\n\nNetanyahu told parliament's Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee on Monday that Biden gave an outline of the deal but not all the details, and he said there are \"gaps.\"\n\nBiden said the first phase of the proposed deal would last for six weeks and include a \"full and complete cease-fire,\" a withdrawal of Israeli forces from all populated areas of Gaza and the release of some hostages, including women, the elderly and the wounded, in exchange for the release of hundreds of Palestinian prisoners.\n\nAmerican hostages would be released at this stage, and remains of hostages who have been killed would be returned to their families. There would be a surge in humanitarian assistance, with 600 trucks a day entering Gaza.\n\nIn the second phase, all the rest of the living hostages would be released, including soldiers, and Israeli forces would withdraw from Gaza. Biden said if Hamas lives up to its commitments, the temporary cease-fire would become a \"cessation of hostilities permanently.\"\n\nAbout 250 people, mainly Israeli civilians, were abducted on Oct. 7, then more than 100 were freed in a short truce in late November and early December. Israel says about 80 hostages are believed to still be captive, alongside the remains of about 43 others.\n\nIsraeli bombardments and ground offensives in Gaza, which Hamas has ruled, have killed more than 36,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry, which does not distinguish between combatants and civilians.\n\nThe third phase of the plan announced by Biden calls for the start of a major reconstruction of Gaza, which faces decades of rebuilding from devastation caused by the war.\n\nThe draft resolution stresses the importance of Israel and Hamas adhering to the deal once it is agreed to, \"with the aim of bringing about a permanent cessation of hostilities, and calls upon all member states and the United Nations to support its implementation.\"\n\nThe draft would also reiterate the council's \"unwavering commitment\" to a two-state solution, and stress the importance of unifying the Gaza Strip and the West Bank under the Palestinian Authority.\n\nThomas-Greenfield, the U.S. ambassador, said Security Council members \"have consistently called for the steps outlined in this deal: bringing the hostages home, ensuring a complete ceasefire, enabling a surge of humanitarian assistance into Gaza and in the refurbishment of essential services, and setting the stage for a long-term reconstruction plan for Gaza.\"\n\n\"Council members should not let this opportunity pass by,\" she said. \"We must speak with one voice in support of this deal.\"\n\nOn Monday, the foreign ministers of five key Arab nations -- Jordan, the United Arab Emirates, Saudi Arabia, Qatar and Egypt -- urged Israel and Hamas to consider Biden's proposal \"seriously and positively.\"\n\nThe group of seven major industrialized nations -- the U.S., Britain, France, Germany, Japan, Canada and Italy -- also backed the cease-fire plan.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "8160761062", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "09:04:03", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T09:04:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T09:03:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://thearabweekly.com/us-ratchets-push-bidens-gaza-truce-proposal-doubts-persist-israelis-feud", "title": "US ratchets up push for Biden's Gaza truce proposal but doubts persist as Israelis feud |  | AW", "body": "Israel's Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich (R) addresses the relatives of Israelis being held hostage by Palestinian Hamas militants in the Gaza Strip, during a rally in the centre of Jerusalem on June 3, 2024. AFP\n\nA few months before its presidential elections, the US is embarked on a multi-pronged campaign to win acceptance of President Joe Biden's proposal for a Gaza truce deal, which is based a three-phase Israeli blueprint for a ceasefire in the enclave in return for the release of Israeli hostages.\n\nDoubts remain as the Israeli government is divided over the proposal. Hamas has not yet given its final response while the US is pressing Doha and Cairo to ensure the militant group's endorsement. Hamas has only said it viewed the proposal \"positively.\"\n\nOn Monday, the US pressed the United Nations Security Council to adopt a resolution backing the proposal.\n\nIt circulated a one-page draft text to the 15-member council.\n\nThe draft calls on Hamas to accept the deal and \"fully and implement its terms without delay and without condition.\"\n\n\"Numerous leaders and governments, including in the region, have endorsed this plan and we call on the Security Council to join them in calling for implementation of this deal without delay and without further conditions,\" US Ambassador Linda Thomas-Greenfield said in a statement.\n\nIn the meanwhile, the fighting showed no sign of easing, with the war that has devastated the coastal territory of 2.4 million people soon to enter its ninth month.\n\nOn Monday, Israel's military said its forces had struck \"over 50 targets\" in the past day, while Gaza hospitals reported at least 19 fatalities in overnight strikes.\n\nIsraeli Prime Minister Binyamin Netanyahu told his hardline governing partners Monday the proposal announced by Biden would meet Israel's goal of destroying Hamas, according to local media.\n\nThe more extremist members of his cabinet have threatened to bring down the government if Netanyahu agreed to a deal that did not eliminate Hamas.\n\nNetanyahu also told parliament on Monday that Biden gave an outline of the deal but not all the details, and he said there were \"gaps.\"\n\nThe leaked quotes from a closed-door parliamentary meeting, which were not immediately confirmed by officials, suggested Israel sees a possibility of entering an initial Gaza truce though it has ruled out ending the war as demanded by Hamas.\n\nBiden had said on May 31 that the first phase of the proposed deal would last for six weeks and include a \"full and complete ceasefire,\" a withdrawal of Israeli forces from all populated areas of Gaza and the release of some hostages, including women, the elderly and the wounded, in exchange for the release of hundreds of Palestinian prisoners.\n\nAmerican hostages would be released at this stage, and remains of hostages who have been killed would be returned to their families. There would be a surge in humanitarian assistance, with 600 trucks a day entering Gaza.\n\nIn the second phase, all the rest of the living hostages would be released, including soldiers, while Israeli forces would withdraw from Gaza. Biden said if Hamas lives up to its commitments, the temporary ceasefire would become a \"cessation of hostilities permanently.\"\n\nLeaders of the Group of Seven (G7) major democracies said in a statement that they \"fully endorse and will stand behind the comprehensive\" ceasefire and hostage release deal.\n\n\"We call on Hamas to accept this deal, that Israel is ready to move forward with, and we urge countries with influence over Hamas to help ensure that it does so,\" the G7 statement said.\n\nThe foreign ministers of Saudi Arabia, Jordan, the United Arab Emirates, Qatar and Egypt also said on Monday it was important to \"deal seriously and positively\" with a proposal presented by US President Joe Biden that would lead to a ceasefire in Gaza, Saudi state news agency (SPA) reported.\n\nThe foreign ministers met virtually to discuss the proposal alongside US-Qatari-Egyptian mediating efforts for an Israeli hostages-Palestinian prisoners swap deal that would lead to a permanent ceasefire and sufficient aid entry into Gaza, SPA added.", "source": {"uri": "thearabweekly.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "AW"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Security Council to support the three-phase plan announced by President Joe Biden aimed at ending the nearly eight-month war in Gaza, freeing hostages and sending massive aid into the devastated territory\n\nUNITED NATIONS (AP) -- The United States urged the U.N. Security Council on Monday to support the three-phase plan announced by President Joe Biden aimed at ending the nearly eight-month war in Gaza, freeing all hostages and sending massive aid into the devastated territory.\n\nU.S. Ambassador Linda Thomas-Greenfield said the United States circulated a draft resolution to the 14 other council members to back the proposal for ending the conflict that began with Hamas' surprise attack in southern Israel on Oct. 7 that killed some 1,200 people, mostly Israeli civilians.\n\n\"Numerous leaders and governments, including in the region, have endorsed this plan and we call on the Security Council to join them in calling for implementation of this deal without delay and without further conditions,\" she said in a statement.\n\nThe brief draft resolution, obtained by The Associated Press, would welcome the May 31 deal announced by Biden and call on Hamas \"to accept it fully and implement its terms without delay and without condition.\" Hamas has said it views the proposal \"positively.\"\n\nIt makes no mention of Israeli acceptance of the deal.\n\nWhen Biden made the announcement he called it an Israeli offer that includes an \"enduring cease-fire\" and Israeli withdrawal from Gaza if Hamas releases all hostages it is holding.\n\nIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu told his hardline governing partners Monday the proposal announced by Biden would meet Israel's goal of destroying Hamas, according to local media. The ultranationalists have threatened to bring down his government if Netanyahu agrees to a deal that doesn't eliminate Hamas.\n\nNetanyahu told parliament's Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee on Monday that Biden gave an outline of the deal but not all the details, and he said there are \"gaps.\"\n\nBiden said the first phase of the proposed deal would last for six weeks and include a \"full and complete cease-fire,\" a withdrawal of Israeli forces from all populated areas of Gaza and the release of some hostages, including women, the elderly and the wounded, in exchange for the release of hundreds of Palestinian prisoners.\n\nAmerican hostages would be released at this stage, and remains of hostages who have been killed would be returned to their families. There would be a surge in humanitarian assistance, with 600 trucks a day entering Gaza.\n\nFeatured Local Savings\n\nIn the second phase, all the rest of the living hostages would be released, including soldiers, and Israeli forces would withdraw from Gaza. Biden said if Hamas lives up to its commitments, the temporary cease-fire would become a \"cessation of hostilities permanently.\"\n\nAbout 250 people, mainly Israeli civilians, were abducted on Oct. 7, then more than 100 were freed in a short truce in late November and early December. Israel says about 80 hostages are believed to still be captive, alongside the remains of about 43 others.\n\nIsraeli bombardments and ground offensives in Gaza, which Hamas has ruled, have killed more than 36,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry, which does not distinguish between combatants and civilians.\n\nThe third phase of the plan announced by Biden calls for the start of a major reconstruction of Gaza, which faces decades of rebuilding from devastation caused by the war.\n\nThe draft resolution stresses the importance of Israel and Hamas adhering to the deal once it is agreed to, \"with the aim of bringing about a permanent cessation of hostilities, and calls upon all member states and the United Nations to support its implementation.\"\n\nThe draft would also reiterate the council's \"unwavering commitment\" to a two-state solution, and stress the importance of unifying the Gaza Strip and the West Bank under the Palestinian Authority.\n\nThomas-Greenfield, the U.S. ambassador, said Security Council members \"have consistently called for the steps outlined in this deal: bringing the hostages home, ensuring a complete ceasefire, enabling a surge of humanitarian assistance into Gaza and in the refurbishment of essential services, and setting the stage for a long-term reconstruction plan for Gaza.\"\n\n\"Council members should not let this opportunity pass by,\" she said. \"We must speak with one voice in support of this deal.\"\n\nOn Monday, the foreign ministers of five key Arab nations -- Jordan, the United Arab Emirates, Saudi Arabia, Qatar and Egypt -- urged Israel and Hamas to consider Biden's proposal \"seriously and positively.\"\n\nThe group of seven major industrialized nations -- the U.S., Britain, France, Germany, Security Council to support the three-phase plan announced by President Joe Biden to end the nearly eight-month war in Gaza, to liberate all the hostages and to send massive aid to the devastated territory. .\n\nU.S. Ambassador Linda Thomas-Greenfield said the United States had circulated a draft resolution to the other 14 council members to support the proposal to end the conflict that began with Hamas' surprise attack in the southern Israel on October 7 which killed some 1,200 people, most of them Israeli civilians. .\n\nMany leaders and governments, including in the region, have endorsed this plan and we call on the Security Council to join them in calling for the implementation of this agreement without delay and without further conditions, she said. declared in a press release.\n\nThe brief draft resolution, obtained by The Associated Press, would welcome the May 31 agreement announced by Biden and call on Hamas to fully accept it and implement its terms without delay and unconditionally. Hamas said it viewed the proposal positively.\n\nIt makes no mention of Israeli acceptance of the deal.\n\nWhen Biden made the announcement, he called it an Israeli offer that includes a lasting ceasefire and an Israeli withdrawal from Gaza if Hamas releases all the hostages it is holding.\n\nIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu told his hardline government partners on Monday that the proposal announced by Biden would achieve Israel's goal of destroying Hamas, according to local media. Ultranationalists have threatened to overthrow his government if Netanyahu accepts a deal that does not eliminate Hamas.\n\nNetanyahu told the House Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee on Monday that Biden had given the broad outlines of the deal but not all the details, and he stressed there were gaps.\n\nBiden said the first phase of the proposed deal would last six weeks and include a full and complete ceasefire, the withdrawal of Israeli forces from all populated areas of Gaza and the release of some hostages, including women, elderly people and the injured. , in exchange for the release of hundreds of Palestinian prisoners.\n\nThe American hostages would be released at this point and the remains of the killed hostages would be returned to their families. There would be an increase in humanitarian aid, with 600 trucks per day entering Gaza.\n\nIn the second phase, all other living hostages would be released, including the soldiers, and Israeli forces would withdraw from Gaza. Biden said that if Hamas follows through on its commitments, the temporary ceasefire would become a permanent cessation of hostilities.\n\nAbout 250 people, mostly Israeli civilians, were kidnapped on October 7, then more than 100 were released during a short truce in late November and early December. Israel says around 80 hostages are believed to remain captive, alongside the remains of around 43 others.\n\nIsraeli bombings and ground offensives in Hamas-controlled Gaza have killed more than 36,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's health ministry, which does not distinguish between fighters and civilians.\n\nThe third phase of the plan announced by Biden calls for the start of a major reconstruction of Gaza, which faces decades of rebuilding after the devastation caused by the war.\n\nThe draft resolution highlights the importance of Israel and Hamas adhering to the agreement once it is concluded, with the aim of achieving a permanent cessation of hostilities, and calls on all member states and the United Nations to support its implementation.\n\nThe draft would also reiterate the Council's unwavering commitment to a two-state solution and emphasize the importance of unifying the Gaza Strip and the West Bank under the Palestinian Authority.\n\nThomas-Greenfield, the U.S. ambassador, said Security Council members have always called for the measures outlined in that deal: bringing the hostages home, ensuring a complete ceasefire, allowing an influx of humanitarian aid in Gaza and the refurbishment of essential services, and paving the way for a long-term reconstruction plan for Gaza.\n\nCouncil members should not let this opportunity pass, she said. We must speak with one voice to support this agreement.\n\nOn Monday, the foreign ministers of five key Arab countries, Jordan, the United Arab Emirates, Saudi Arabia, Qatar and Egypt, urged Israel and Hamas to consider Biden's proposal seriously and positively .\n\nThe Group of Seven major industrialized countries, namely the United States, Britain, France, Germany, Japan, Canada and Italy, {"uri": "8160249201", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "02:01:36", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T02:01:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T01:55:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/politics/2728447/", "title": "Biden takes a major turn in the hostages-for-truce agreement and requires Israeli and Hamas officials to intensify their efforts - ExBulletin", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) President Joe Biden looks past resistance from top Israeli officials as he pressures Israel and Hamas to agree to a three-phase deal that could immediately bring home dozens of Israeli hostages, free Palestinian prisoners and perhaps even lead to an endgame in the nearly eight-month-old Gaza war.\n\nBiden's big turnaround during a tough re-election battle could also demonstrate to a significant portion of his political base demoralized by his handling of the conflict that he is doing his part to end the war that has killed more than 36 000 Palestinians and left hundreds of thousands struggling to reunite. basic needs.\n\nWhite House officials said Monday that Biden's decision to make public what he described as an Israeli proposal just a day after it was delivered to Hamas was motivated by a desire to embarrass Hamas. The move was a departure from the U.S. administration's position throughout the conflict, which was to allow the Israelis to speak for themselves regarding hostage negotiations.\n\nThe president felt that where we are in this war, where we are in the negotiations to release the hostages, it was time to take a different approach and make the proposal public, to try to energize the process here and catalyze a different outcome, said White House national security spokesman John Kirby.\n\nAlmost immediately after Biden detailed the proposal that includes a ceasefire and a gradual withdrawal of Israeli troops from Gaza if Hamas releases all hostages, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office said he would continue its war until 'until Hamas is destroyed.\n\nNetanyahu's political survival depends on a far-right coalition single-mindedly committed to eradicating Hamas. He sowed more doubts about the viability of the proposal on Monday when he told an Israeli parliamentary committee that there were some flaws in the way Biden presented the proposal. The prime minister said the Israelis reserved the right to return to war.\n\nKirby downplayed the differences between Biden and Netanyahu and stressed that the proposal was Israeli. He added that Biden agrees with the Israelis that Hamas should not rule Gaza after the war, nor does he expect Israel to have to live alongside that kind of terrorist threat. \"\n\nIt wasn't about blocking the prime minister or the war cabinet, Kirby said. It was about showing the public with what quality, with what fidelity and with what confidence the Israelis had presented a new proposal. This shows how much they really want this to happen. \"\n\nBut even if Hamas agreed to the terms, it would force Netanyahu to make difficult political calculations. Two leaders of his far-right coalition, National Security Minister Itamar Ben-Gvir and Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich, have threatened to leave Netanyahu's government if he signs the proposal. This would lead to the collapse of the coalition.\n\nSmotrich said Monday that agreeing to a ceasefire would amount to humiliation of Israel and capitulation. According to him, increased military pressure is the only language understood in the Middle East.\n\nBiden expressed concern last week that members of the Israeli government want to continue fighting for years and do not view the release of hostages as a \"priority.\" Administration officials warned Israeli officials on Monday that getting bogged down in Gaza could be detrimental to Israel's national security.\n\nEndless conflict in Gaza in pursuit of an idea of total victory will not make Israel more secure,\" said State Department spokesperson Matthew Miller.\n\nNetanyahu also faced pressure from the hostages' families. Officials say about 80 people captured by militants in the Oct. 7 attack are still alive and Hamas is holding the bodies of 43 others to reach a deal to free their loved ones. Opposition leader Yair Lapid, however, pledged over the weekend to provide a political safety net for Netanyahu, ensuring his government would not fall over the deal.\n\nAlthough the proposal faces significant challenges, the Biden administration has said it is cautiously optimistic that a deal can be reached.\n\nWhite House national security adviser Jake Sullivan urged world leaders to get behind the proposal.\n\nThey need to pay attention to Hamas this week and say it's time to come to the table to make this deal, Sullivan said during an appearance at the US Global Leadership Coalition conference in Washington.\n\nTo that end, Biden spoke Monday with Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani of Qatar, a key Hamas interlocutor, and said this was the best possible opportunity for a deal, the White House said.\n\nAmbassador Linda Thomas-Greenfield, the U.S. envoy to the United Nations, said the United States had circulated a draft resolution seeking support for the proposal from the other 14 members of the U.N. Security Council .\n\nSullivan, meanwhile, spoke to his Turkish counterpart, Akif Cagatay Kilic, about Turkey's use of its influence with Hamas to get it to accept the proposal. Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan defended Hamas and hosted the group's political leader, Ismail Haniyeh, for talks in April.\n\nOn Monday, Group of Seven leaders also approved the deal.\n\n\"We call on Hamas to accept this agreement, that Israel is ready to move forward, and we urge countries with influence over Hamas to help ensure that it does so,\" the G7 leaders said in a press release.\n\nBiden acknowledged last week that it would be difficult to move past the first phase of the proposal.\n\nThe first phase would last six weeks and include a ceasefire, the withdrawal of Israeli forces from all densely populated areas of Gaza and the release of a number of hostages, including women, the elderly and the wounded. , in exchange for the release of hundreds of Palestinian prisoners.\n\nThe Israelis, under the proposal, would also allow 600 humanitarian aid trucks into Gaza each day during the first phase. The second phase would include the release of all remaining hostages, including male soldiers, and the withdrawal of Israeli forces from Gaza.\n\nHamas is likely to make huge demands on which Palestinian prisoners will be released and call on Israel to guarantee that it will not continue targeting Hamas' top leaders.\n\nAaron David Miller, a former US Middle East peace negotiator, said that even moving to the first phase and the six-week pause in fighting would lead to a slowdown in the escalation of the military campaign and a decrease in the number of deaths.\n\nI'm not sure they can expect much more, said Miller, now a senior fellow at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. Ultimately, negotiations only work if the parties feel enough pain accompanied by the prospect of gain, which generates urgency. The only party that is in a hurry here is the Biden administration. \"\n\nIndeed, Israeli officials are considering the conflict over a much longer period.\n\nLast week, Israeli national security adviser Tzachi Hanegbi said he expected the war to drag on for another seven months, in order to destroy the military and government capabilities of Hamas and the smaller group Islamic Jihad activist.\n\nBut with U.S. Election Day just over five months away, Biden faces growing pressure to more quickly resolve the Middle East conflict that is causing him to lose support.\n\nAP writers Edith M. Lederer at the United Nations and Matthew Lee contributed reporting.", "source": {"uri": "exbulletin.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ExBulletin"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8160467821", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "05:38:36", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T05:38:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T05:37:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.expressandstar.com/news/world-news/2024/06/04/us-urges-un-security-council-to-support-gaza-ceasefire-plan/", "title": "US urges UN Security Council to support Gaza ceasefire plan", "body": "The three-phase plan announced by President Joe Biden is aimed at ending the eight-month war in Gaza.\n\nThe United States has urged the UN Security Council to support a three-phase plan announced by President Joe Biden aimed at ending the eight-month war in Gaza, freeing all hostages and sending massive aid into the devastated territory.\n\nUS Ambassador Linda Thomas-Greenfield said the United States circulated a draft resolution to the 14 other council members to back the proposal for ending the conflict.\n\n\"Numerous leaders and governments, including in the region, have endorsed this plan and we call on the Security Council to join them in calling for implementation of this deal without delay and without further conditions,\" she said in a statement.\n\nThe brief draft resolution, obtained by The Associated Press, would welcome the May 31 deal announced by Mr Biden and call on Hamas \"to accept it fully and implement its terms without delay and without condition.\" Hamas has said it views the proposal \"positively\".\n\nIt makes no mention of Israeli acceptance of the deal.\n\nWhen Mr Biden made the announcement he called it an Israeli offer that includes an \"enduring ceasefire\" and Israeli withdrawal from Gaza if Hamas releases all hostages it is holding.\n\nIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu told his hardline governing partners on Monday the proposal announced by Mr Biden would meet Israel's goal of destroying Hamas, according to local media. The ultranationalists have threatened to bring down his government if Mr Netanyahu agrees to a deal that does not eliminate Hamas.\n\nMr Netanyahu told parliament's Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee on Monday that Mr Biden gave an outline of the deal but not all the details and he said there are \"gaps\".\n\nThe US president said the first phase of the proposed deal would last for six weeks and include a \"full and complete ceasefire,\" a withdrawal of Israeli forces from all populated areas of Gaza and the release of some hostages, including women, the elderly and the wounded, in exchange for the release of hundreds of Palestinian prisoners.\n\nAmerican hostages would be released at this stage and remains of hostages who have been killed would be returned to their families. There would be a surge in humanitarian assistance with 600 trucks a day entering Gaza.\n\nIn the second phase, all the rest of the living hostages would be released, including soldiers, and Israeli forces would withdraw from Gaza.\n\nMr Biden said if Hamas lives up to its commitments, the temporary ceasefire would become a \"cessation of hostilities permanently\".\n\nAbout 250 people, mainly Israeli civilians, were abducted on October 7 with more than 100 were freed in a short truce in late November and early December. Israel says about 80 hostages are believed to still be captive, alongside the remains of about 43 others.\n\nIsraeli bombardments and ground offensives in Gaza, which Hamas has ruled, have killed more than 36,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry, which does not distinguish between combatants and civilians.\n\nThe third phase of the plan announced by Mr Biden calls for the start of a major reconstruction of Gaza, which faces decades of rebuilding from devastation caused by the war.\n\nThe draft resolution stresses the importance of Israel and Hamas adhering to the deal once it is agreed to, \"with the aim of bringing about a permanent cessation of hostilities, and calls upon all member states and the United Nations to support its implementation.\"\n\nThe draft would also reiterate the council's \"unwavering commitment\" to a two-state solution and stress the importance of unifying the Gaza Strip and the West Bank under the Palestinian Authority.\n\nThe US ambassador said Security Council members \"have consistently called for the steps outlined in this deal: bringing the hostages home, ensuring a complete ceasefire, enabling a surge of humanitarian assistance into Gaza and in the refurbishment of essential services, and setting the stage for a long-term reconstruction plan for Gaza.\"\n\n\"Council members should not let this opportunity pass by,\" she said. \"We must speak with one voice in support of this deal.\"\n\nOn Monday, the foreign ministers of five key Arab nations -- Jordan, the United Arab Emirates, Saudi Arabia, Qatar and Egypt -- urged Israel and Hamas to consider Mr Biden's proposal \"seriously and positively.\"\n\nThe group of seven major industrialised nations -- the US, Britain, France, Germany, Japan, Canada and Italy -- also {"uri": "8160480921", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "05:50:04", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T05:50:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T05:49:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.euronews.com/2024/06/04/us-urges-un-security-council-to-support-israel-hamas-ceasefire-plan", "title": "US urges UN Security Council to support Israel Hamas ceasefire plan", "body": "Biden has announced a three-phase plan aimed at ending the war in Gaza. Now he is seeking international backing for it.\n\nWashington urged the UN Security Council on Monday to support a ceasefire plan between Israel and Hamas, which would free all hostages and send massive amounts of aid into Gaza.\n\nThe three-part proposal aimed at ending the nearly eight-month war was announced by US President Joe Biden on 31 May. Now he is trying to drum up support at the international organisation.\n\n\"Numerous leaders and governments, including in the region, have endorsed this plan and we call on the Security Council to join them in calling for implementation of this deal without delay and without further conditions,\" said US Ambassador Linda Thomas-Greenfield in a statement.\n\nBiden has called on Hamas to accept the deal \"fully and implement its terms without delay and without condition.\" The Palestinian militant group has said it views the proposal \"positively.\"\n\nThe draft resolution shown to the UN Security Council makes no mention of Israeli acceptance of the deal.\n\nIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu told his hardline governing partners on Monday the proposal would still allow Israel to meet the goal of destroying Hamas, according to local media.\n\nUltranationalists have threatened to topple his government if Netanyahu agrees to a deal that doesn't eliminate Hamas.\n\nNetanyahu has not outlined all the details of the ceasefire proposal, but said on Monday there were \"gaps\".\n\nBiden said the first phase of the plan would last for six weeks and include a \"full and complete ceasefire,\" a withdrawal of Israeli forces from all populated areas of Gaza and the release of some hostages, including women, the elderly and the wounded, in exchange for the freeing of hundreds of Palestinian prisoners.\n\nUS hostages would be released at this stage, with the remains of hostages who have been killed returned to their families also. There would be a surge in humanitarian assistance, with 600 trucks a day entering Gaza.\n\nIn the second phase, all the rest of the living hostages would be released, including soldiers, and Israeli forces would withdraw from Gaza.\n\nBiden said if Hamas lives up to its commitments, the temporary ceasefire would become a \"cessation of hostilities permanently.\"\n\nThe third phase of the plan announced by the US leader calls for the start of a major reconstruction of Gaza, which faces decades of rebuilding from devastation caused by the war.\n\nThe war has damaged or destroyed approximately 62 percent of all homes in the Palestinian enclave, leaving more than a million people without homes, according to estimates by the World Bank and UN.\n\nAbout 250 people, mainly Israeli civilians, were take hostage in Hamas' surprise 7 October attack on southern Israel, which killed 1,200 people.\n\nMore than 100 were freed in a short truce in late November and early December. Israel says about 80 hostages are believed to still be captive, alongside the remains of about 43 others.\n\nIsraeli bombardments and ground offensives in Gaza have killed more than 36,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry. {"uri": "8160477955", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "05:48:27", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T05:48:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T05:47:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.breakingnews.ie/israel-hamas/us-urges-un-security-council-to-support-gaza-ceasefire-plan-1633371.html", "title": "US urges UN Security Council to support Gaza ceasefire plan | BreakingNews.ie", "body": "The United States has urged the UN Security Council to support a three-phase plan announced by President Joe Biden aimed at ending the eight-month war in Gaza, freeing all hostages and sending massive aid into the devastated territory.\n\nUS Ambassador Linda Thomas-Greenfield said the United States circulated a draft resolution to the 14 other council members to back the proposal for ending the conflict.\n\n\"Numerous leaders and governments, including in the region, have endorsed this plan and we call on the Security Council to join them in calling for implementation of this deal without delay and without further conditions,\" she said in a statement.\n\nThe brief draft resolution, obtained by The Associated Press, would welcome the May 31st deal announced by Mr Biden and call on Hamas \"to accept it fully and implement its terms without delay and without condition.\" Hamas has said it views the proposal \"positively\".\n\nIt makes no mention of Israeli acceptance of the deal.\n\nWhen Mr Biden made the announcement he called it an Israeli offer that includes an \"enduring ceasefire\" and Israeli withdrawal from Gaza if Hamas releases all hostages it is holding.\n\nIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu told his hardline governing partners on Monday the proposal announced by Mr Biden would meet Israel's goal of destroying Hamas, according to local media. The ultranationalists have threatened to bring down his government if Mr Netanyahu agrees to a deal that does not eliminate Hamas.\n\nMr Netanyahu told parliament's Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee on Monday that Mr Biden gave an outline of the deal but not all the details and he said there are \"gaps\".\n\nThe US president said the first phase of the proposed deal would last for six weeks and include a \"full and complete ceasefire,\" a withdrawal of Israeli forces from all populated areas of Gaza and the release of some hostages, including women, the elderly and the wounded, in exchange for the release of hundreds of Palestinian prisoners.\n\nAmerican hostages would be released at this stage and the remains of hostages who have been killed would be returned to their families. There would be a surge in humanitarian assistance with 600 trucks a day entering Gaza.\n\nIn the second phase, all the rest of the living hostages would be released, including soldiers, and Israeli forces would withdraw from Gaza.\n\nMr Biden said if Hamas lives up to its commitments, the temporary ceasefire would become a \"cessation of hostilities permanently\".\n\nAbout 250 people, mainly Israeli civilians, were abducted on October 7th with more than 100 freed in a short truce in late November and early December. Israel says about 80 hostages are believed to still be captive, alongside the remains of about 43 others.\n\nIsraeli bombardments and ground offensives in Gaza, which Hamas has ruled, have killed more than 36,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry, which does not distinguish between combatants and civilians.\n\nThe third phase of the plan announced by Mr Biden calls for the start of a major reconstruction of Gaza, which faces decades of rebuilding from devastation caused by the war.\n\nThe draft resolution stresses the importance of Israel and Hamas adhering to the deal once it is agreed to, \"with the aim of bringing about a permanent cessation of hostilities, and calls upon all member states and the United Nations to support its implementation.\"\n\nThe draft would also reiterate the council's \"unwavering commitment\" to a two-state solution and stress the importance of unifying the Gaza Strip and the West Bank under the Palestinian Authority.\n\nThe US ambassador said Security Council members \"have consistently called for the steps outlined in this deal: bringing the hostages home, ensuring a complete ceasefire, enabling a surge of humanitarian assistance into Gaza and in the refurbishment of essential services, and setting the stage for a long-term reconstruction plan for Gaza.\"\n\n\"Council members should not let this opportunity pass by,\" she said. \"We must speak with one voice in support of this deal.\"\n\nOn Monday, the foreign ministers of five key Arab nations -- Jordan, the United Arab Emirates, Saudi Arabia, Qatar and Egypt -- urged Israel and Hamas to consider Mr Biden's proposal \"seriously and positively.\"\n\nThe group of seven major industrialised nations -- the US, Britain, France, Germany, Japan, Canada and Italy -- also {"uri": "8160617038", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "07:30:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T07:30:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T07:29:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.irishtimes.com/world/middle-east/2024/06/04/israel-hamas-war-gaza-strip-latest-news/", "title": "Israel-Gaza war: US urges UN Security Council to support ceasefire plan", "body": "Biden's three-phase plan aims to end eight-month war in Gaza, free all hostages and send massive aid into territory\n\nThe United States has urged the UN Security Council to support a three-phase plan announced by President Joe Biden aimed at ending the eight-month war in Gaza, freeing all hostages and sending massive aid into the devastated territory.\n\nUS ambassador Linda Thomas-Greenfield said the United States circulated a draft resolution to the 14 other council members to back the proposal for ending the conflict.\n\n\"Numerous leaders and governments, including in the region, have endorsed this plan and we call on the security council to join them in calling for implementation of this deal without delay and without further conditions,\" she said in a statement.\n\nThe brief draft resolution would welcome the May 31st deal announced by Mr Biden and call on Hamas \"to accept it fully and implement its terms without delay and without condition\".\n\nHamas has said it views the proposal \"positively\".\n\nIt makes no mention of Israeli acceptance of the deal.\n\nWhen Mr Biden made the announcement he called it an Israeli offer that includes an \"enduring ceasefire\" and Israeli withdrawal from Gaza if Hamas releases all hostages it is holding.\n\nIsraeli prime minister Binyamin Netanyahu told his hardline governing partners on Monday the proposal announced by Mr Biden would meet Israel's goal of destroying Hamas, according to local media. The ultranationalists have threatened to bring down his government if Mr Netanyahu agrees to a deal that does not eliminate Hamas.\n\nMr Netanyahu told parliament's foreign affairs and defence committee on Monday that Mr Biden gave an outline of the deal but not all the details and he said there are \"gaps\".\n\nThe US president said the first phase of the proposed deal would last for six weeks and include a \"full and complete ceasefire\", a withdrawal of Israeli forces from all populated areas of Gaza and the release of some hostages - including women, the elderly and the wounded - in exchange for the release of hundreds of Palestinian prisoners.\n\nAmerican hostages would be released at this stage, and remains of hostages who have been killed would be returned to their families. There would be a surge in humanitarian assistance with 600 trucks a day entering Gaza.\n\nIn the second phase, all the rest of the living hostages would be released, including soldiers, and Israeli forces would withdraw from Gaza.\n\nMr Biden said if Hamas lives up to its commitments, the temporary ceasefire would become a \"cessation of hostilities permanently\".\n\nAbout 250 people, mainly Israeli civilians, were abducted on October 7th with more than 100 were freed in a short truce in late November and early December. Israel says about 80 hostages are believed to still be captive, alongside the remains of about 43 others.\n\nIsraeli bombardments and ground offensives in Gaza, which Hamas has ruled, have killed more than 36,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry, which does not distinguish between combatants and civilians.\n\nThe third phase of the plan announced by Mr Biden calls for the start of a major reconstruction of Gaza, which faces decades of rebuilding from devastation caused by the war.\n\nThe draft resolution stresses the importance of Israel and Hamas adhering to the deal once it is agreed to, \"with the aim of bringing about a permanent cessation of hostilities, and calls upon all member states and the United Nations to support its implementation.\"\n\nThe draft would also reiterate the council's \"unwavering commitment\" to a two-state solution and stress the importance of unifying the Gaza Strip and the West Bank under the Palestinian Authority.\n\nThe US ambassador said security council members \"have consistently called for the steps outlined in this deal: bringing the hostages home, ensuring a complete ceasefire, enabling a surge of humanitarian assistance into Gaza and in the refurbishment of essential services, and setting the stage for a long-term reconstruction plan for Gaza\".\n\n\"Council members should not let this opportunity pass by,\" she said. \"We must speak with one voice in support of this deal.\"\n\nOn Monday, the foreign ministers of five key Arab nations - Jordan, the United Arab Emirates, Saudi Arabia, Qatar and Egypt - urged Israel and Hamas to consider Mr Biden's proposal \"seriously and positively.\"\n\nThe group of seven major industrialised nations - the United States, Britain, France, Germany, Japan, Canada and Italy {"uri": "8161222763", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "13:46:37", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T13:46:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T13:45:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.military.com/daily-news/2024/06/04/biden-takes-big-swing-hostage-truce-deal-puts-onus-israeli-hamas-officials-step.html", "title": "Biden Takes a Big Swing at Hostage-for-Truce Deal, Puts Onus on Israeli, Hamas Officials to Step Up", "body": "WASHINGTON -- President Joe Biden is looking past resistance from key Israeli officials as he presses Israel and Hamas to agree to a three-phase agreement that could immediately bring home dozens of Israeli hostages, free Palestinian prisoners and perhaps even lead to an endgame in the nearly eight-month-old Gaza war.\n\nBiden's big swing -- during a tough reelection battle -- could also demonstrate to a significant slice of his political base demoralized by his handling of the conflict that he's doing his part to end the war that has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians and left hundreds of thousands struggling to meet basic needs.\n\nWhite House officials on Monday said Biden's decision to make public what it describes as an Israeli proposal -- just one day after it was delivered to Hamas -- was driven by a desire to put Hamas on the spot. The move diverged from the U.S. administration's position throughout the conflict to allow the Israelis to speak for themselves about hostage negotiations.\n\n\"The president felt that where we are in this war, where we are in the negotiations to get the hostages out, that it was time for a different approach and a time to make the proposal public, to try to energize the process here and catalyze a different outcome,\" White House national security spokesman John Kirby said.\n\nAlmost immediately after Biden detailed the proposal -- which includes a cease-fire and phased Israeli troop withdrawal from Gaza if Hamas releases all hostages -- Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office said it would continue its war until Hamas was destroyed.\n\nNetanyahu's political survival depends on a far-right coalition that is adamant about eradicating Hamas. He sowed further doubt about proposal's viability Monday when he told an Israeli parliament committee that there are certain \"gaps\" in how Biden laid out the proposal. The prime minister said Israelis \"reserve the right to return to war.\"\n\nKirby played down differences between Biden and Netanyahu and underscored that the proposal was an Israeli one. He added that Biden agrees with Israelis that Hamas should not govern postwar Gaza nor does he \"expect that Israel should have to live next door to that kind of a terrorist threat.\"\n\n\"This wasn't about jamming the prime minister, the war cabinet,\" Kirby said. \"This was about laying bare for the public to see how well and how faithfully and how assertively the Israelis came up with a new proposal. It shows how much they really want to get this done.\"\n\nBut even if Hamas agreed to terms, it would require Netanyahu to make some difficult political calculations. Two leading members of his far-right coalition -- National Security Minister Itamar Ben-Gvir and Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich -- have threatened to leave Netanyahu's government if he signs off on the proposal. That would cause the coalition to collapse.\n\nSmotrich said Monday that agreeing to a cease-fire would amount to a humiliation of Israel and a surrender. Increased military pressure, he said, is \"the only language understood in the Middle East.\"\n\nBiden last week expressed concern about those in the Israeli government who \"want to keep fighting for years\" and don't see freeing the hostages as a \"priority.\" Administration officials on Monday warned Israeli officials that getting bogged down in Gaza could be detrimental to Israel's national security.\n\n\"Endless conflict in Gaza in pursuit of some idea of total victory is not going to make Israel safer,\" said State Department spokesman Matthew Miller.\n\nNetanyahu has also faced pressure from families of hostages -- officials say about 80 people captured by militants i n the Oct. 7 attack are still alive and Hamas is holding the bodies of 43 others -- to reach an agreement to free their loved ones. Opposition leader Yair Lapid, however, vowed over the weekend to provide a political safety net to Netanyahu, ensuring his government would not fall over the deal.\n\nEven as the proposal faces stiff headwinds, the Biden administration said it was cautiously optimistic that a deal could be reached.\n\nWhite House national security adviser Jake Sullivan urged world leaders to rally behind the proposal.\n\n\"They need to train their eyes on Hamas this week and say it's time to come to the table to do this deal,\" Sullivan said in an appearance at the U.S. Global Leadership Coalition conference in Washington.\n\nTo that end, Biden on Monday spoke with Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani of Qatar, a key Hamas interlocutor, and said it was \"the best possible opportunity for an agreement,\" the White House said.\n\nAmbassador Linda Thomas-Greenfield, the U.S. envoy to the United Nations, said the U.S. circulated a draft resolution seeking support for the proposal from the 14 other members of the U.N. Security Council.\n\nSullivan, meanwhile, spoke to his Turkish counterpart, Akif Cagatay Kilic, about Turkey using its influence with Hamas to get them to accept the proposal. Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has defended Hamas and hosted the group's political leader, Ismail Haniyeh, for talks in April.\n\nGroup of Seven leaders on Monday also endorsed the deal.\n\n\"We call on Hamas to accept this deal, that Israel is ready to move forward with, and we urge countries with influence over Hamas to help ensure that it does so,\" the G7 leaders said in a statement.\n\nBiden acknowledged last week that getting beyond the first phase of the proposal would be difficult.\n\nThe first phase would last for six weeks and would include a cease-fire, a withdrawal of Israeli forces from all densely populated areas of Gaza and the release of a number of hostages, including women, the elderly and the wounded, in exchange for the release of hundreds of Palestinian prisoners.\n\nThe Israelis, under the proposal, would also allow 600 humanitarian aid trucks into Gaza each day during the first phase. The second phase would include the release of all remaining living hostages, including male soldiers, and Israeli forces would withdraw from Gaza.\n\nHamas is likely to make enormous demands about which Palestinian prisoners will be released and call on Israel to assure that it won't continue to target top Hamas leaders.\n\nAaron David Miller, a former U.S. Middle East peace negotiator, said even getting to phase one -- and the six-week pause in fighting -- would bring about a \"downshift in the escalation of the military campaign, fewer people dying.\"\n\n\"I'm not sure they can expect much more,\" said Miller, now a senior fellow at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. \"Negotiations work in the end only if the parties feel sufficient pain accompanied by the prospects of gain, and that generates urgency. The only party that is in a hurry here is the Biden administration.\"\n\nIndeed, Israeli officials view the conflict on a far longer timeline.\n\nJust last week, Israeli national security adviser Tzachi Hanegbi said he expected the war to drag on for another seven months, in order to destroy the military and governing capabilities of Hamas and the smaller Islamic Jihad militant group.\n\nBut with Election Day in the U.S. now just over five months away, Biden faces tightening pressure to more quickly resolve the Mideast conflict that's left him bleeding support.\n\n--\n\nAP writers Edith M. Lederer at the United Nations and Matthew Lee contributed reporting.", "source": {"uri": "military.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Military"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri":
