{"uri": "8160462574", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "05:34:36", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T05:34:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T05:33:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/news/national/24363725.us-urges-un-security-council-support-gaza-ceasefire-plan/", "title": "US urges UN Security Council to support Gaza ceasefire plan", "body": "US Ambassador Linda Thomas-Greenfield said the United States circulated a draft resolution to the 14 other council members to back the proposal for ending the conflict.\n\n\"Numerous leaders and governments, including in the region, have endorsed this plan and we call on the Security Council to join them in calling for implementation of this deal without delay and without further conditions,\" she said in a statement.\n\nThe brief draft resolution, obtained by The Associated Press, would welcome the May 31 deal announced by Mr Biden and call on Hamas \"to accept it fully and implement its terms without delay and without condition.\" Hamas has said it views the proposal \"positively\".\n\nIt makes no mention of Israeli acceptance of the deal.\n\nWhen Mr Biden made the announcement he called it an Israeli offer that includes an \"enduring ceasefire\" and Israeli withdrawal from Gaza if Hamas releases all hostages it is holding.\n\nIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu told his hardline governing partners on Monday the proposal announced by Mr Biden would meet Israel's goal of destroying Hamas, according to local media. The ultranationalists have threatened to bring down his government if Mr Netanyahu agrees to a deal that does not eliminate Hamas.\n\nMr Netanyahu told parliament's Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee on Monday that Mr Biden gave an outline of the deal but not all the details and he said there are \"gaps\".\n\nThe US president said the first phase of the proposed deal would last for six weeks and include a \"full and complete ceasefire,\" a withdrawal of Israeli forces from all populated areas of Gaza and the release of some hostages, including women, the elderly and the wounded, in exchange for the release of hundreds of Palestinian prisoners.\n\nAmerican hostages would be released at this stage and remains of hostages who have been killed would be returned to their families. There would be a surge in humanitarian assistance with 600 trucks a day entering Gaza.\n\nIn the second phase, all the rest of the living hostages would be released, including soldiers, and Israeli forces would withdraw from Gaza.\n\nMr Biden said if Hamas lives up to its commitments, the temporary ceasefire would become a \"cessation of hostilities permanently\".\n\nAbout 250 people, mainly Israeli civilians, were abducted on October 7 with more than 100 were freed in a short truce in late November and early December. Israel says about 80 hostages are believed to still be captive, alongside the remains of about 43 others.\n\nIsraeli bombardments and ground offensives in Gaza, which Hamas has ruled, have killed more than 36,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry, which does not distinguish between combatants and civilians.\n\nThe third phase of the plan announced by Mr Biden calls for the start of a major reconstruction of Gaza, which faces decades of rebuilding from devastation caused by the war.\n\nThe draft resolution stresses the importance of Israel and Hamas adhering to the deal once it is agreed to, \"with the aim of bringing about a permanent cessation of hostilities, and calls upon all member states and the United Nations to support its implementation.\"\n\nThe draft would also reiterate the council's \"unwavering commitment\" to a two-state solution and stress the importance of unifying the Gaza Strip and the West Bank under the Palestinian Authority.\n\nThe US ambassador said Security Council members \"have consistently called for the steps outlined in this deal: bringing the hostages home, ensuring a complete ceasefire, enabling a surge of humanitarian assistance into Gaza and in the refurbishment of essential services, and setting the stage for a long-term reconstruction plan for Gaza.\"\n\n\"Council members should not let this opportunity pass by,\" she said. \"We must speak with one voice in support of this deal.\"\n\nOn Monday, the foreign ministers of five key Arab nations -- Jordan, the United Arab Emirates, Saudi Arabia, Qatar and Egypt -- urged Israel and Hamas to consider Mr Biden's proposal \"seriously and positively.\"\n\nThe group of seven major industrialised nations -- the US, Britain, France, Germany, Japan, Canada and Italy -- also {"uri": "8160467011", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "05:37:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T05:37:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T05:37:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://jerseyeveningpost.com/morenews/worldnews/2024/06/04/us-urges-un-security-council-to-support-gaza-ceasefire-plan/", "title": "US urges UN Security Council to support Gaza ceasefire plan", "body": "The United States has urged the UN Security Council to support a three-phase plan announced by President Joe Biden aimed at ending the eight-month war in Gaza, freeing all hostages and sending massive aid into the devastated territory.\n\nUS Ambassador Linda Thomas-Greenfield said the United States circulated a draft resolution to the 14 other council members to back the proposal for ending the conflict.\n\n\"Numerous leaders and governments, including in the region, have endorsed this plan and we call on the Security Council to join them in calling for implementation of this deal without delay and without further conditions,\" she said in a statement.\n\nIt makes no mention of Israeli acceptance of the deal.\n\nWhen Mr Biden made the announcement he called it an Israeli offer that includes an \"enduring ceasefire\" and Israeli withdrawal from Gaza if Hamas releases all hostages it is holding.\n\nIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu told his hardline governing partners on Monday the proposal announced by Mr Biden would meet Israel's goal of destroying Hamas, according to local media. The ultranationalists have threatened to bring down his government if Mr Netanyahu agrees to a deal that does not eliminate Hamas.\n\nMr Netanyahu told parliament's Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee on Monday that Mr Biden gave an outline of the deal but not all the details and he said there are \"gaps\".\n\nThe US president said the first phase of the proposed deal would last for six weeks and include a \"full and complete ceasefire,\" a withdrawal of Israeli forces from all populated areas of Gaza and the release of some hostages, including women, the elderly and the wounded, in exchange for the release of hundreds of Palestinian prisoners.\n\nIn the second phase, all the rest of the living hostages would be released, including soldiers, and Israeli forces would withdraw from Gaza.\n\nMr Biden said if Hamas lives up to its commitments, the temporary ceasefire would become a \"cessation of hostilities permanently\".\n\nAbout 250 people, mainly Israeli civilians, were abducted on October 7 with more than 100 were freed in a short truce in late November and early December. Israel says about 80 hostages are believed to still be captive, alongside the remains of about 43 others.\n\nIsraeli bombardments and ground offensives in Gaza, which Hamas has ruled, have killed more than 36,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry, which does not distinguish between combatants and civilians.\n\nThe third phase of the plan announced by Mr Biden calls for the start of a major reconstruction of Gaza, which faces decades of rebuilding from devastation caused by the war.\n\nThe draft resolution stresses the importance of Israel and Hamas adhering to the deal once it is agreed to, \"with the aim of bringing about a permanent cessation of hostilities, and calls upon all member states and the United Nations to support its implementation.\"\n\nThe draft would also reiterate the council's \"unwavering commitment\" to a two-state solution and stress the importance of unifying the Gaza Strip and the West Bank under the Palestinian Authority.\n\nThe US ambassador said Security Council members \"have consistently called for the steps outlined in this deal: bringing the hostages home, ensuring a complete ceasefire, enabling a surge of humanitarian assistance into Gaza and in the refurbishment of essential services, and setting the stage for a long-term reconstruction plan for Gaza.\"\n\n\"Council members should not let this opportunity pass by,\" she said. \"We must speak with one voice in support of this deal.\"\n\nOn Monday, the foreign ministers of five key Arab nations -- Jordan, the United Arab Emirates, Saudi Arabia, Qatar and Egypt -- urged Israel and Hamas to consider Mr Biden's proposal \"seriously and positively.\"\n\nThe group of seven major industrialised nations -- the US, Britain, France, Germany, Japan, Canada and Italy -- also {"uri": "8161610263", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "18:16:05", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T18:16:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T18:15:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.voazimbabwe.com/a/biden-every-reason-to-believe-netanyahu-dragging-out-gaza-war-to-save-himself-politically/7642576.html", "title": "Biden: 'Every Reason' to Believe Netanyahu Dragging Out Gaza War to Save Himself Politically", "body": "U.S. President Joe Biden, increasingly critical of Israel's conduct of its war against Hamas militants in Gaza as the death toll of Palestinians mounts, says in a new interview that there is \"every reason\" to believe Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has dragged out the conflict to save himself politically.\n\nAs the war nears the eight-month mark, the Israeli leader faces conflicting demands from Biden and other world leaders to end the conflict, while right-wing lawmakers in the Israeli parliament say they will abandon support for Netanyahu and upend his government if he agrees to a cease-fire without erasing the last vestiges of Hamas control in Gaza.\n\nBiden last week announced an Israeli proposal for a Gaza cease-fire and pushed for world support of it. But Hamas has yet to agree to it, and Netanyahu has since been reserved in his comments about it. Days before, Time magazine asked Biden in an interview whether he believed Netanyahu was dragging out the war for political self-preservation.\n\n\"There is every reason for people to draw that conclusion,\" Biden replied in the interview, which was published Tuesday.\n\nBiden acknowledged that he and Netanyahu have had tense relations as the death toll in Gaza has soared past the 36,000 mark, a figure that includes civilians and combatants. They are particularly at odds over whether a revitalized Palestinian Authority should govern Gaza after the war, which the United States favors and Netanyahu rejects without offering a detailed plan of his own.\n\n\"My major disagreement with Netanyahu is, what happens after ... Gaza's over? What, what does it go back to? Do Israeli forces go back in?\" Biden asked rhetorically.\n\n\"The answer is, if that's the case, it can't work,\" he said.\n\nThis image contains sensitive content which some people may find offensive or disturbing.Click to reveal\n\nThe fate of a proposal to halt fighting in Gaza for six weeks and increase humanitarian aid while Hamas releases some hostages it is holding in exchange for Palestinians jailed in Israel remained uncertain Tuesday. Hamas has yet to respond to the proposal, Israeli officials are questioning some of the details and the United States is seeking U.N. Security Council support for the deal's acceptance and implementation.\n\nA draft U.S. resolution seen by VOA calls on Hamas to fully accept and implement the cease-fire proposal \"without delay and without condition.\"\n\nThe draft says, \"Swift implementation of this deal would enable a cease-fire, withdrawal of Israeli forces from populated areas in Gaza, the release of hostages, a surge in humanitarian assistance, restoration of basic services, and the return of Palestinian civilians to northern Gaza.\"\n\nU.S. State Department spokesperson Matthew Miller told reporters Monday that Hamas, which received the cease-fire proposal Thursday, had yet to respond. He said the key elements of the proposal \"are nearly identical to the major elements of the proposal that Hamas submitted several weeks ago.\"\n\nThe basic outline of the deal includes a six-week halt in fighting, the release of some hostages from Gaza, daily deliveries of 600 trucks of aid for Palestinians and further negotiations aimed at securing a permanent end to the conflict.\n\nU.S. officials reiterated Monday that the cease-fire proposal, although presented publicly by Biden last week, is an Israeli proposal.\n\nWhite House national security spokesperson John Kirby told reporters that making public negotiations that officials have declined to reveal in the past for fear of disrupting the negotiation process was not about putting pressure on Israeli officials, but rather, if anything, publicly pressuring Hamas and its leaders to accept the deal.\n\n\"The president felt that where we are in this war, where we are in the negotiations to get the hostages out, that it was time for a different approach and a time to make the proposal public, to try to energize the process here, catalyze a different outcome,\" Kirby said.\n\nSmoke plumes billow near tents sheltering displaced Palestinians in Rafah, in the southern Gaza Strip, on June 4, 2024.\n\nKirby said in earlier comments to reporters that if Hamas were to accept the proposal, Israel would as well.\n\nNetanyahu told a parliamentary committee Monday that \"claims that we have agreed to a cease-fire without our conditions being met are incorrect,\" according to a statement from his office.\n\nIsrael said, \"The war will be stopped for the purpose of returning the hostages\" after which discussions would follow on how to achieve Israel's goal of eliminating Hamas.\n\nLeaders of the Group of Seven leading industrial nations issued a joint statement Monday fully endorsing the cease-fire proposal.\n\n\"We call on Hamas to accept this deal, that Israel is ready to move forward with, and we urge countries with influence over Hamas to help ensure that it does so,\" the statement said.\n\nThe foreign ministers of Egypt, Jordan, Saudi Arabia, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates said after a virtual meeting Monday that they support efforts to negotiate a permanent cease-fire, while emphasizing \"dealing seriously and positively\" with the proposal outlined by Biden.\n\nThe ministers called for Israel's full withdrawal from the Gaza Strip, the return of displaced Palestinians to areas they fled, the launch of reconstruction efforts in Gaza, and the implementation of a two-state solution, according to a statement released by Jordan's foreign ministry.\n\nHamas launched a terror attack October 7 on Israel, killing about 1,200 people according to Israeli tallies, and taking roughly 250 hostages. About 120 of the hostages remain in Gaza, although the Israeli military says 37 of them are dead.\n\nIsrael's retaliatory bombardments and ground offensive have killed at least 36,400 people in Gaza, mostly civilians, according to the Gaza Health Ministry.\n\nSome information for this report was provided by The Associated Press, Reuters and Agence France-Presse.", "source": {"uri": "dmoz/Health/Public_Health_and_Safety", "label": "dmoz/Health/Public Health and Safety", "wgt": 10}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare_and_Conflict", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare and "https://gdb.voanews.com/f13e2564-1a3a-4191-bc68-a44c148cbda3_w1200_r1.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9618758", "eventUri": "eng-9618758", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "-10-07", "textStart": 5495, "textEnd": 5504}], "sentiment": -0.3411764705882353, "wgt": 197, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-06-377802141", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "01:56:30", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T01:56:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T23:18:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://tribtown.com/2024/06/03/biden-takes-a-big-swing-at-hostage-for-truce-deal-puts-onus-on-israeli-hamas-officials-to-step-up/", "title": "Biden takes a big swing at hostage-for-truce deal, puts onus on Israeli, Hamas officials to step up", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- President Joe Biden is looking past resistance from key Israeli officials as he presses Israel and Hamas to agree to a three-phase agreement that could immediately bring home dozens of Israeli hostages, free Palestinian prisoners and perhaps even lead to an endgame in the nearly eight-month-old Gaza war.\n\nBiden's big swing -- during a tough reelection battle -- could also demonstrate to a significant slice of his political base demoralized by his handling of the conflict that he's doing his part to end the war that has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians and left hundreds of thousands struggling to meet basic needs.\n\nWhite House officials on Monday said Biden's decision to make public what it describes as an Israeli proposal -- just one day after it was delivered to Hamas -- was driven by a desire to put Hamas on the spot. The move diverged from the U.S. administration's position throughout the conflict to allow the Israelis to speak for themselves about hostage negotiations.\n\n\"The president felt that where we are in this war, where we are in the negotiations to get the hostages out, that it was time for a different approach and a time to make the proposal public, to try to energize the process here and catalyze a different outcome,\" White House national security spokesman John Kirby said.\n\nAlmost immediately after Biden detailed the proposal -- which includes a cease-fire and phased Israeli troop withdrawal from Gaza if Hamas releases all hostages -- Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office said it would continue its war until Hamas was destroyed.\n\nNETANYAHU FACING PRESSURE FROM FAR-RIGHT\n\nNetanyahu's political survival depends on a far-right coalition that is adamant about eradicating Hamas. He sowed further doubt about proposal's viability Monday when he told an Israeli parliament committee that there are certain \"gaps\" in how Biden laid out the proposal. The prime minister said Israelis \"reserve the right to return to war.\"\n\nKirby played down differences between Biden and Netanyahu and underscored that the proposal was an Israeli one. He added that Biden agrees with Israelis that Hamas should not govern postwar Gaza nor does he \"expect that Israel should have to live next door to that kind of a terrorist threat.\"\n\n\"This wasn't about jamming the prime minister, the war cabinet,\" Kirby said. \"This was about laying bare for the public to see how well and how faithfully and how assertively the Israelis came up with a new proposal. It shows how much they really want to get this done.\"\n\nBut even if Hamas agreed to terms, it would require Netanyahu to make some difficult political calculations. Two leading members of his far-right coalition -- National Security Minister Itamar Ben-Gvir and Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich -- have threatened to leave Netanyahu's government if he signs off on the proposal. That would cause the coalition to collapse.\n\nSmotrich said Monday that agreeing to a cease-fire would amount to a humiliation of Israel and a surrender. Increased military pressure, he said, is \"the only language understood in the Middle East.\"\n\nBiden last week expressed concern about those in the Israeli government who \"want to keep fighting for years\" and don't see freeing the hostages as a \"priority.\" Administration officials on Monday warned Israeli officials that getting bogged down in Gaza could be detrimental to Israel's national security.\n\n\"Endless conflict in Gaza in pursuit of some idea of total victory is not going to make Israel safer,\" said State Department spokesman Matthew Miller.\n\nNetanyahu has also faced pressure from families of hostages -- officials say about 80 people captured by militants i n the Oct. 7 attack are still alive and Hamas is holding the bodies of 43 others -- to reach an agreement to free their loved ones. Opposition leader Yair Lapid, however, vowed over the weekend to provide a political safety net to Netanyahu, ensuring his government would not fall over the deal.\n\nOPTIMISM DESPITE HEADWINDS\n\nEven as the proposal faces stiff headwinds, the Biden administration said it was cautiously optimistic that a deal could be reached.\n\nWhite House national security adviser Jake Sullivan urged world leaders to rally behind the proposal.\n\n\"They need to train their eyes on Hamas this week and say it's time to come to the table to do this deal,\" Sullivan said in an appearance at the U.S. Global Leadership Coalition conference in Washington.\n\nTo that end, Biden on Monday spoke with Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani of Qatar, a key Hamas interlocutor, and said it was \"the best possible opportunity for an agreement,\" the White House said.\n\nAmbassador Linda Thomas-Greenfield, the U.S. envoy to the United Nations, said the U.S. circulated a draft resolution seeking support for the proposal from the 14 other members of the U.N. Security Council.\n\nSullivan, meanwhile, spoke to his Turkish counterpart, Akif Cagatay Kilic, about Turkey using its influence with Hamas to get them to accept the proposal. Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has defended Hamas and hosted the group's political leader, Ismail Haniyeh, for talks in April.\n\nGroup of Seven leaders on Monday also endorsed the deal.\n\n\"We call on Hamas to accept this deal, that Israel is ready to move forward with, and we urge countries with influence over Hamas to help ensure that it does so,\" the G7 leaders said in a statement.\n\nEVEN GETTING TO PHASE ONE IS A CHALLENGE\n\nBiden acknowledged last week that getting beyond the first phase of the proposal would be difficult.\n\nThe first phase would last for six weeks and would include a cease-fire, a withdrawal of Israeli forces from all densely populated areas of Gaza and the release of a number of hostages, including women, the elderly and the wounded, in exchange for the release of hundreds of Palestinian prisoners.\n\nThe Israelis, under the proposal, would also allow 600 humanitarian aid trucks into Gaza each day during the first phase. The second phase would include the release of all remaining living hostages, including male soldiers, and Israeli forces would withdraw from Gaza.\n\nHamas is likely to make enormous demands about which Palestinian prisoners will be released and call on Israel to assure that it won't continue to target top Hamas leaders.\n\nAaron David Miller, a former U.S. Middle East peace negotiator, said even getting to phase one -- and the six-week pause in fighting -- would bring about a \"downshift in the escalation of the military campaign, fewer people dying.\"\n\n\"I'm not sure they can expect much more,\" said Miller, now a senior fellow at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. \"Negotiations work in the end only if the parties feel sufficient pain accompanied by the prospects of gain, and that generates urgency. The only party that is in a hurry here is the Biden administration.\"\n\nIndeed, Israeli officials view the conflict on a far longer timeline.\n\nJust last week, Israeli national security adviser Tzachi Hanegbi said he expected the war to drag on for another seven months, in order to destroy the military and governing capabilities of Hamas and the smaller Islamic Jihad militant group.\n\nBut with Election Day in the U.S. now just over five months away, Biden faces tightening pressure to more quickly resolve the Mideast conflict that's left him bleeding support.\n\n--\n\nAP writers Edith M. Lederer at the United Nations and Matthew Lee contributed reporting.", "source": {"uri": "tribtown.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-378021066", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "07:07:44", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T07:07:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T01:31:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.channel3000.com/news/national-and-world-news/israel-conflict/biden-takes-a-big-swing-at-hostage-for-truce-deal-puts-onus-on-israeli-hamas/article_f3662f9a-8ea4-51cf-9ad2-b2aad477729b.html", "title": "Biden takes a big swing at hostage-for-truce deal, puts onus on Israeli, Hamas officials to step up", "body": "President Joe Biden is looking past resistance from key Israeli officials as he presses Israel and Hamas to agree to a three-phase agreement including an extended truce\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- President Joe Biden is looking past resistance from key Israeli officials as he presses Israel and Hamas to agree to a three-phase agreement that could immediately bring home dozens of Israeli hostages, free Palestinian prisoners and perhaps even lead to an endgame in the nearly eight-month-old Gaza war.\n\nBiden's big swing -- during a tough reelection battle -- could also demonstrate to a significant slice of his political base demoralized by his handling of the conflict that he's doing his part to end the war that has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians and left hundreds of thousands struggling to meet basic needs.\n\nWhite House officials on Monday said Biden's decision to make public what it describes as an Israeli proposal -- just one day after it was delivered to Hamas -- was driven by a desire to put Hamas on the spot. The move diverged from the U.S. administration's position throughout the conflict to allow the Israelis to speak for themselves about hostage negotiations.\n\n\"The president felt that where we are in this war, where we are in the negotiations to get the hostages out, that it was time for a different approach and a time to make the proposal public, to try to energize the process here and catalyze a different outcome,\" White House national security spokesman John Kirby said.\n\nAlmost immediately after Biden detailed the proposal -- which includes a cease-fire and phased Israeli troop withdrawal from Gaza if Hamas releases all hostages -- Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office said it would continue its war until Hamas was destroyed.\n\nNETANYAHU FACING PRESSURE FROM FAR-RIGHT\n\nNetanyahu's political survival depends on a far-right coalition that is adamant about eradicating Hamas. He sowed further doubt about proposal's viability Monday when he told an Israeli parliament committee that there are certain \"gaps\" in how Biden laid out the proposal. The prime minister said Israelis \"reserve the right to return to war.\"\n\nKirby played down differences between Biden and Netanyahu and underscored that the proposal was an Israeli one. He added that Biden agrees with Israelis that Hamas should not govern postwar Gaza nor does he \"expect that Israel should have to live next door to that kind of a terrorist threat.\"\n\n\"This wasn't about jamming the prime minister, the war cabinet,\" Kirby said. \"This was about laying bare for the public to see how well and how faithfully and how assertively the Israelis came up with a new proposal. It shows how much they really want to get this done.\"\n\nBut even if Hamas agreed to terms, it would require Netanyahu to make some difficult political calculations. Two leading members of his far-right coalition -- National Security Minister Itamar Ben-Gvir and Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich -- have threatened to leave Netanyahu's government if he signs off on the proposal. That would cause the coalition to collapse.\n\nSmotrich said Monday that agreeing to a cease-fire would amount to a humiliation of Israel and a surrender. Increased military pressure, he said, is \"the only language understood in the Middle East.\"\n\nBiden last week expressed concern about those in the Israeli government who \"want to keep fighting for years\" and don't see freeing the hostages as a \"priority.\" Administration officials on Monday warned Israeli officials that getting bogged down in Gaza could be detrimental to Israel's national security.\n\n\"Endless conflict in Gaza in pursuit of some idea of total victory is not going to make Israel safer,\" said State Department spokesman Matthew Miller.\n\nNetanyahu has also faced pressure from families of hostages -- officials say about 80 people captured by militants i n the Oct. 7 attack are still alive and Hamas is holding the bodies of 43 others -- to reach an agreement to free their loved ones. Opposition leader Yair Lapid, however, vowed over the weekend to provide a political safety net to Netanyahu, ensuring his government would not fall over the deal.\n\nOPTIMISM DESPITE HEADWINDS\n\nEven as the proposal faces stiff headwinds, the Biden administration said it was cautiously optimistic that a deal could be reached.\n\nWhite House national security adviser Jake Sullivan urged world leaders to rally behind the proposal.\n\n\"They need to train their eyes on Hamas this week and say it's time to come to the table to do this deal,\" Sullivan said in an appearance at the U.S. Global Leadership Coalition conference in Washington.\n\nTo that end, Biden on Monday spoke with Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani of Qatar, a key Hamas interlocutor, and said it was \"the best possible opportunity for an agreement,\" the White House said.\n\nAmbassador Linda Thomas-Greenfield, the U.S. envoy to the United Nations, said the U.S. circulated a draft resolution seeking support for the proposal from the 14 other members of the U.N. Security Council.\n\nSullivan, meanwhile, spoke to his Turkish counterpart, Akif Cagatay Kilic, about Turkey using its influence with Hamas to get them to accept the proposal. Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has defended Hamas and hosted the group's political leader, Ismail Haniyeh, for talks in April.\n\nGroup of Seven leaders on Monday also endorsed the deal.\n\n\"We call on Hamas to accept this deal, that Israel is ready to move forward with, and we urge countries with influence over Hamas to help ensure that it does so,\" the G7 leaders said in a statement.\n\nEVEN GETTING TO PHASE ONE IS A CHALLENGE\n\nBiden acknowledged last week that getting beyond the first phase of the proposal would be difficult.\n\nThe first phase would last for six weeks and would include a cease-fire, a withdrawal of Israeli forces from all densely populated areas of Gaza and the release of a number of hostages, including women, the elderly and the wounded, in exchange for the release of hundreds of Palestinian prisoners.\n\nThe Israelis, under the proposal, would also allow 600 humanitarian aid trucks into Gaza each day during the first phase. The second phase would include the release of all remaining living hostages, including male soldiers, and Israeli forces would withdraw from Gaza.\n\nHamas is likely to make enormous demands about which Palestinian prisoners will be released and call on Israel to assure that it won't continue to target top Hamas leaders.\n\nAaron David Miller, a former U.S. Middle East peace negotiator, said even getting to phase one -- and the six-week pause in fighting -- would bring about a \"downshift in the escalation of the military campaign, fewer people dying.\"\n\n\"I'm not sure they can expect much more,\" said Miller, now a senior fellow at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. \"Negotiations work in the end only if the parties feel sufficient pain accompanied by the prospects of gain, and that generates urgency. The only party that is in a hurry here is the Biden administration.\"\n\nIndeed, Israeli officials view the conflict on a far longer timeline.\n\nJust last week, Israeli national security adviser Tzachi Hanegbi said he expected the war to drag on for another seven months, in order to destroy the military and governing capabilities of Hamas and the smaller Islamic Jihad militant group.\n\nBut with Election Day in the U.S. now just over five months away, Biden faces tightening pressure to more quickly resolve the Mideast conflict that's left him bleeding support.\n\n--\n\nAP writers Edith M. Lederer at the United Nations and Matthew Lee contributed reporting.\n\nCOPYRIGHT 2024 BY CHANNEL 3000. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. {"uri": "8160245618", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "01:51:06", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T01:51:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T01:50:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/us/biden-takes-a-big-swing-at-hostage-for-truce-deal-puts-onus-on-israeli-hamas-officials-to-step-up/articleshow/110684865.cms", "title": "Biden takes a big swing at hostage-for-truce deal, puts onus on Israeli, Hamas officials to step up - Times of India", "body": "WASHINGTON: President Joe Biden is looking past resistance from key Israeli officials as he presses Israel and Hamas to agree to a three-phase agreement that could immediately bring home dozens of Israeli hostages, free Palestinian prisoners and perhaps even lead to an endgame in the nearly eight-month-old Gaza war.\n\nBiden's big swing - during a tough reelection battle - could also demonstrate to a significant slice of his political base demoralized by his handling of the conflict that he's doing his part to end the war that has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians and left hundreds of thousands struggling to meet basic needs.\n\nWhite House officials on Monday said Biden's decision to make public what it describes as an Israeli proposal - just one day after it was delivered to Hamas - was driven by a desire to put Hamas on the spot. The move diverged from the US administration's position throughout the conflict to allow the Israelis to speak for themselves about hostage negotiations.\n\n\"The president felt that where we are in this war, where we are in the negotiations to get the hostages out, that it was time for a different approach and a time to make the proposal public, to try to energize the process here and catalyze a different outcome,\" White House national security spokesman John Kirby said.\n\nAlmost immediately after Biden detailed the proposal - which includes a cease-fire and phased Israeli troop withdrawal from Gaza if Hamas releases all hostages - Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office said it would continue its war until Hamas was destroyed.\n\nNetanyahu's political survival depends on a far-right coalition that is adamant about eradicating Hamas. He sowed further doubt about proposal's viability Monday when he told an Israeli parliament committee that there are certain \"gaps\" in how Biden laid out the proposal. The prime minister said Israelis \"reserve the right to return to war.\"\n\nKirby played down differences between Biden and Netanyahu and underscored that the proposal was an Israeli one. He added that Biden agrees with Israelis that Hamas should not govern postwar Gaza nor does he \"expect that Israel should have to live next door to that kind of a terrorist threat.\"\n\n\"This wasn't about jamming the prime minister, the war cabinet,\" Kirby said. \"This was about laying bare for the public to see how well and how faithfully and how assertively the Israelis came up with a new proposal. It shows how much they really want to get this done.\"\n\nBut even if Hamas agreed to terms, it would require Netanyahu to make some difficult political calculations. Two leading members of his far-right coalition - National Security Minister Itamar Ben-Gvir and Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich - have threatened to leave Netanyahu's government if he signs off on the proposal. That would cause the coalition to collapse.\n\nSmotrich said Monday that agreeing to a cease-fire would amount to a humiliation of Israel and a surrender. Increased military pressure, he said, is \"the only language understood in the Middle East.\"\n\nNetanyahu has also faced pressure from families of hostages - officials say about 80 people captured by militants i n the Oct. 7 attack are still alive and Hamas is holding the bodies of 43 others - to reach an agreement to free their loved ones. Opposition leader Yair Lapid, however, vowed over the weekend to provide a political safety net to Netanyahu, ensuring his government would not fall over the deal.\n\nEven as the proposal faces stiff headwinds, the Biden administration said it was cautiously optimistic that a deal could be reached.\n\nWhite House national security adviser Jake Sullivan urged world leaders to rally behind the proposal.\n\n\"They need to train their eyes on Hamas this week and say it's time to come to the table to do this deal,\" Sullivan said in an appearance at the US Global Leadership Conference in Washington.\n\nTo that end, Biden on Monday spoke with Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani of Qatar, a key Hamas interlocutor, and said it was \"the best possible opportunity for an agreement,\" the White House said.\n\nAmbassador Linda Thomas-Greenfield, the US envoy to the United Nations, said the US circulated a draft resolution seeking support for the proposal from the 14 other members of the U.N. Security Council.\n\nSullivan, meanwhile, spoke to his Turkish counterpart, Akif Cagatay Kilic, about Turkey using its influence with Hamas to get them to accept the proposal. Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has defended Hamas and hosted the group's political leader, Ismail Haniyeh, for talks in April.\n\nGroup of Seven leaders on Monday also endorsed the deal.\n\n\"We call on Hamas to accept this deal, that Israel is ready to move forward with, and we urge countries with influence over Hamas to help ensure that it does so,\" the G7 leaders said in a statement.\n\nBiden acknowledged last week that getting beyond the first phase of the proposal would be difficult.\n\nThe first phase would last for six weeks and would include a cease-fire, a withdrawal of Israeli forces from all densely populated areas of Gaza and the release of a number of hostages, including women, the elderly and the wounded, in exchange for the release of hundreds of Palestinian prisoners.\n\nThe Israelis, under the proposal, would also allow 600 humanitarian aid trucks into Gaza each day during the first phase. The second phase would include the release of all remaining living hostages, including male soldiers, and Israeli forces would withdraw from Gaza.\n\nHamas is likely to make enormous demands about which Palestinian prisoners will be released and call on Israel to assure that it won't continue to target top Hamas leaders.\n\nAaron David Miller, a former US Middle East peace negotiator, said even getting to phase one - and the six-week pause in fighting - would bring about a \"downshift in the escalation of the military campaign, fewer people dying.\"\n\n\"I'm not sure they can expect much more,\" said Miller, now a senior fellow at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. \"Negotiations work in the end only if the parties feel sufficient pain accompanied by the prospects of gain, and that generates urgency. The only party that is in a hurry here is the Biden administration.\"\n\nIndeed, Israeli officials view the conflict on a far longer timeline.\n\nJust last week, Israeli national security adviser Tzachi Hanegbi said he expected the war to drag on for another seven months, in order to destroy the military and governing capabilities of Hamas and the smaller Islamic Jihad militant group.\n\nBut with Election Day in the US now just over five months away, Biden faces tightening pressure to more quickly resolve the Mideast conflict that's left him bleeding support.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-378020595", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "07:06:41", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T07:06:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T07:06:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/58/1262/524759/War-on-Gaza/War-on-Gaza/US-urges-UN-Security-Council-to-support-ceasefire-.aspx", "title": "US urges UN Security Council to support cease-fire plan in Gaza announced by President Biden", "body": "U.S. Ambassador Linda Thomas-Greenfield said the United States circulated a draft resolution to the 14 other council members to back the proposal for ending the conflict.\n\n\"Numerous leaders and governments, including in the region, have endorsed this plan and we call on the Security Council to join them in calling for implementation of this deal without delay and without further conditions,\" she said.\n\nThe brief draft resolution, obtained by The Associated Press, would welcome the May 31 deal announced by Biden and call on Hamas \"to accept it fully and implement its terms without delay and without condition.\" Hamas has said it views the proposal \"positively.\"\n\nIt makes no mention of Israeli acceptance of the deal.\n\nWhen Biden made the announcement he called it an Israeli offer that includes an \"enduring cease-fire\" and Israeli withdrawal from Gaza if Hamas releases all captives it is holding.\n\nIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu told his hardline governing partners Monday that the proposal announced by Biden would meet Israel's goal of destroying Hamas, according to local media. The ultranationalists have threatened to bring down his government if Netanyahu agrees to a deal that doesn't \"eliminate\" Hamas.\n\nNetanyahu told parliament's Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee on Monday that Biden gave an outline of the deal but not all the details, and he said there are \"gaps.\"\n\nBiden said the first phase of the proposed deal would last for six weeks and include a \"full and complete cease-fire,\" a withdrawal of Israeli forces from all populated areas of Gaza and the release of some hostages, including women, the elderly and the wounded, in exchange for the release of hundreds of Palestinian prisoners.\n\nAmerican captives would be released at this stage, and the remains of hostages who had been killed would be returned to their families. There would be a surge in humanitarian assistance, with 600 trucks entering Gaza daily.\n\nIn the second phase, all the rest of the living captives would be released, including soldiers, and Israeli forces would withdraw from Gaza. Biden said if Hamas lives up to its commitments, the temporary cease-fire would become a \"cessation of hostilities permanently.\"\n\nAbout 250 people, mainly Israeli civilians, were abducted on Oct. 7, then more than 100 were freed in a short truce in late November and early December. Israel says about 80 captives are believed to still in Gaza, alongside the remains of about 43 others.\n\nIsraeli bombardments and ground offensives in Gaza, which Hamas has ruled, have killed more than 36,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry, most of them women and children.\n\nThe third phase of the plan announced by Biden calls for the start of a major reconstruction of Gaza, which faces decades of rebuilding from devastation caused by the Israeli war.\n\nThe draft resolution stresses the importance of Israel and Hamas adhering to the deal once it is agreed to, \"with the aim of bringing about a permanent cessation of hostilities, and calls upon all member states and the United Nations to support its implementation.\"\n\nThe draft would also reiterate the council's \"unwavering commitment\" to a two-state solution, and stress the importance of unifying the Gaza Strip and the West Bank under the Palestinian Authority.\n\nThomas-Greenfield, the U.S. ambassador, said Security Council members \"have consistently called for the steps outlined in this deal: bringing the hostages home, ensuring a complete ceasefire, enabling a surge of humanitarian assistance into Gaza and in the refurbishment of essential services, and setting the stage for a long-term reconstruction plan for Gaza.\"\n\n\"Council members should not let this opportunity pass by,\" she said. \"We must speak with one voice in support of this deal.\"\n\nOn Monday, the foreign ministers of five key Arab nations -- Jordan, the United Arab Emirates, Saudi Arabia, Qatar and Egypt -- urged Israel and Hamas to consider Biden's proposal \"seriously and positively.\"\n\nThe group of seven major industrialised nations -- the U.S., Britain, France, Germany, Japan, Canada and Italy -- also "eng-9618758", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-05-31", "textStart": 486, "textEnd": 492}, {"amb": false, "date": "-10-07", "textStart": 2290, "textEnd": {"uri": "8160145463", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "23:51:57", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T23:51:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T23:49:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13491043/Biden-takes-big-swing-hostage-truce-deal-puts-onus-Israeli-Hamas-officials-step-up.html", "title": "Biden takes a big swing at hostage-for-truce deal, puts onus on...", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) - President Joe Biden is looking past resistance from key Israeli officials as he presses Israel and Hamas to agree to a three-phase agreement that could immediately bring home dozens of Israeli hostages, free Palestinian prisoners and perhaps even lead to an endgame in the nearly eight-month-old Gaza war.\n\nBiden's big swing - during a tough reelection battle - could also demonstrate to a significant slice of his political base demoralized by his handling of the conflict that he's doing his part to end the war that has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians and left hundreds of thousands struggling to meet basic needs.\n\nWhite House officials on Monday said Biden's decision to make public what it describes as an Israeli proposal - just one day after it was delivered to Hamas - was driven by a desire to put Hamas on the spot. The move diverged from the U.S. administration's position throughout the conflict to allow the Israelis to speak for themselves about hostage negotiations.\n\n\"The president felt that where we are in this war, where we are in the negotiations to get the hostages out, that it was time for a different approach and a time to make the proposal public, to try to energize the process here and catalyze a different outcome,\" White House national security spokesman John Kirby said.\n\nAlmost immediately after Biden detailed the proposal - which includes a cease-fire and phased Israeli troop withdrawal from Gaza if Hamas releases all hostages - Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office said it would continue its war until Hamas was destroyed.\n\nNetanyahu's political survival depends on a far-right coalition that is adamant about eradicating Hamas. He sowed further doubt about proposal's viability Monday when he told an Israeli parliament committee that there are certain \"gaps\" in how Biden laid out the proposal. The prime minister said Israelis \"reserve the right to return to war.\"\n\nPresident Joe Biden delivers remarks on the verdict in former President Donald Trump's hush money trial and on the Middle East, from the State Dining Room of the White House, Friday, May 31, 2024, in Washington. (AP Photo/Evan Vucci)\n\nKirby played down differences between Biden and Netanyahu and underscored that the proposal was an Israeli one. He added that Biden agrees with Israelis that Hamas should not govern postwar Gaza nor does he \"expect that Israel should have to live next door to that kind of a terrorist threat.\"\n\n\"This wasn't about jamming the prime minister, the war cabinet,\" Kirby said. \"This was about laying bare for the public to see how well and how faithfully and how assertively the Israelis came up with a new proposal. It shows how much they really want to get this done.\"\n\nBut even if Hamas agreed to terms, it would require Netanyahu to make some difficult political calculations. Two leading members of his far-right coalition - National Security Minister Itamar Ben-Gvir and Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich - have threatened to leave Netanyahu\u00b4s government if he signs off on the proposal. That would cause the coalition to collapse.\n\nSmotrich said Monday that agreeing to a cease-fire would amount to a humiliation of Israel and a surrender. Increased military pressure, he said, is \"the only language understood in the Middle East.\"\n\nNetanyahu has also faced pressure from families of hostages - officials say about 80 people captured by militants i n the Oct. 7 attack are still alive and Hamas is holding the bodies of 43 others - to reach an agreement to free their loved ones. Opposition leader Yair Lapid, however, vowed over the weekend to provide a political safety net to Netanyahu, ensuring his government would not fall over the deal.\n\nEven as the proposal faces stiff headwinds, the Biden administration said it was cautiously optimistic that a deal could be reached.\n\nWhite House national security adviser Jake Sullivan urged world leaders to rally behind the proposal.\n\n\"They need to train their eyes on Hamas this week and say it\u00b4s time to come to the table to do this deal,\" Sullivan said in an appearance at the U.S. Global Leadership Conference in Washington.\n\nTo that end, Biden on Monday spoke with Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani of Qatar, a key Hamas interlocutor, and said it was \"the best possible opportunity for an agreement,\" the White House said.\n\nSullivan, meanwhile, spoke to his Turkish counterpart, Akif Cagatay Kilic, about Turkey using its influence with Hamas to get them to accept the proposal. Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has defended Hamas and hosted the group's political leader, Ismail Haniyeh, for talks in April.\n\nGroup of Seven leaders on Monday also endorsed the deal.\n\n\"We call on Hamas to accept this deal, that Israel is ready to move forward with, and we urge countries with influence over Hamas to help ensure that it does so,\" the G7 leaders said in a statement.\n\nBiden acknowledged last week that getting beyond the first phase of the proposal would be difficult.\n\nThe first phase would last for six weeks and would include a cease-fire, a withdrawal of Israeli forces from all densely populated areas of Gaza and the release of a number of hostages, including women, the elderly and the wounded, in exchange for the release of hundreds of Palestinian prisoners.\n\nThe Israelis, under the proposal, would also allow 600 humanitarian aid trucks into Gaza each day during the first phase. The second phase would include the release of all remaining living hostages, including male soldiers, and Israeli forces would withdraw from Gaza.\n\nHamas is likely to make enormous demands about which Palestinian prisoners will be released and call on Israel to assure that it won't continue to target top Hamas leaders.\n\nAaron David Miller, a former U.S. Middle East peace negotiator, said even getting to phase one - and the six-week pause in fighting - would bring about a \"downshift in the escalation of the military campaign, fewer people dying.\"\n\n\"I\u00b4m not sure they can expect much more,\" said Miller, now a senior fellow at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. \"Negotiations work in the end only if the parties feel sufficient pain accompanied by the prospects of gain, and that generates urgency. The only party that is in a hurry here is the Biden administration.\"\n\nIndeed, Israeli officials view the conflict on a far longer timeline.\n\nJust last week, Israeli national security adviser Tzachi Hanegbi said he expected the war to drag on for another seven months, in order to destroy the military and governing capabilities of Hamas and the smaller Islamic Jihad militant group.\n\nBut with Election Day in the U.S. now just over five months away, Biden faces tightening pressure to more quickly resolve the Mideast conflict that\u00b4s left him bleeding support.\n\nPresident Joe Biden delivers remarks on the verdict in former President Donald Trump's hush money trial and on the Middle East, from the State Dining Room of the White House, Friday, May 31, 2024, in Washington. (AP Photo/Evan Vucci)\n\nIsraeli police remove a person protesting against Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's government as demonstrators call for the release of hostages held in the Gaza Strip by the Hamas militant group, in Tel Aviv, Israel, Saturday, June 1, 2024. (AP Photo/Maya Alleruzzo)", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palestinians", {"uri": "8160884818", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "10:18:12", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T10:18:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T10:17:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/news/world/u-s-urges-un-security-council-to-support-cease-fire-plan-in-gaza-announced-by/article_96ac6dbe-bb39-59ca-8341-3c18de4b380c.html", "title": "U.S. urges UN Security Council to support cease-fire plan in Gaza announced by President Biden", "body": "UNITED NATIONS (AP) -- The United States urged the U.N. Security Council on Monday to support the three-phase plan announced by President Joe Biden aimed at ending the nearly eight-month war in Gaza, freeing all hostages and sending massive aid into the devastated territory.\n\nU.S. Ambassador Linda Thomas-Greenfield said the United States circulated a draft resolution to the 14 other council members to back the proposal for ending the conflict that began with Hamas' surprise attack in southern Israel on Oct. 7 that killed some 1,200 people, mostly Israeli civilians.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\n\"Numerous leaders and governments, including in the region, have endorsed this plan and we call on the Security Council to join them in calling for implementation of this deal without delay and without further conditions,\" she said in a statement.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThe brief draft resolution, obtained by The Associated Press, would welcome the May 31 deal announced by Biden and call on Hamas \"to accept it fully and implement its terms without delay and without condition.\" Hamas has said it views the proposal \"positively.\"\n\nIt makes no mention of Israeli acceptance of the deal.\n\nWhen Biden made the announcement he called it an Israeli offer that includes an \"enduring cease-fire\" and Israeli withdrawal from Gaza if Hamas releases all hostages it is holding.\n\nIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu told his hardline governing partners Monday the proposal announced by Biden would meet Israel's goal of destroying Hamas, according to local media. The ultranationalists have threatened to bring down his government if Netanyahu agrees to a deal that doesn't eliminate Hamas.\n\nNetanyahu told parliament's Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee on Monday that Biden gave an outline of the deal but not all the details, and he said there are \"gaps.\"\n\nBiden said the first phase of the proposed deal would last for six weeks and include a \"full and complete cease-fire,\" a withdrawal of Israeli forces from all populated areas of Gaza and the release of some hostages, including women, the elderly and the wounded, in exchange for the release of hundreds of Palestinian prisoners.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nAmerican hostages would be released at this stage, and remains of hostages who have been killed would be returned to their families. There would be a surge in humanitarian assistance, with 600 trucks a day entering Gaza.\n\nIn the second phase, all the rest of the living hostages would be released, including soldiers, and Israeli forces would withdraw from Gaza. Biden said if Hamas lives up to its commitments, the temporary cease-fire would become a \"cessation of hostilities permanently.\"\n\nAbout 250 people, mainly Israeli civilians, were abducted on Oct. 7, then more than 100 were freed in a short truce in late November and early December. Israel says about 80 hostages are believed to still be captive, alongside the remains of about 43 others.\n\nIsraeli bombardments and ground offensives in Gaza, which Hamas has ruled, have killed more than 36,000 Palestinians, according to Gaza's Health Ministry, which does not distinguish between combatants and civilians.\n\nThe third phase of the plan announced by Biden calls for the start of a major reconstruction of Gaza, which faces decades of rebuilding from devastation caused by the war.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThe draft resolution stresses the importance of Israel and Hamas adhering to the deal once it is agreed to, \"with the aim of bringing about a permanent cessation of hostilities, and calls upon all member states and the United Nations to support its implementation.\"\n\nThe draft would also reiterate the council's \"unwavering commitment\" to a two-state solution, and stress the importance of unifying the Gaza Strip and the West Bank under the Palestinian Authority.\n\nThomas-Greenfield, the U.S. ambassador, said Security Council members \"have consistently called for the steps outlined in this deal: bringing the hostages home, ensuring a complete ceasefire, enabling a surge of humanitarian assistance into Gaza and in the refurbishment of essential services, and setting the stage for a long-term reconstruction plan for Gaza.\"\n\n\"Council members should not let this opportunity pass by,\" she said. \"We must speak with one voice in support of this deal.\"\n\nOn Monday, the foreign ministers of five key Arab nations -- Jordan, the United Arab Emirates, Saudi Arabia, Qatar and Egypt -- urged Israel and Hamas to consider Biden's proposal \"seriously and positively.\"\n\nThe group of seven major industrialized nations -- the U.S., Britain, France, Germany, Japan, Canada and Italy -- also backed the cease-fire plan.", "source": {"uri": "thestar.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Star"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "2024-06-377734093", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "23:33:15", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T23:33:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T19:18:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/politics/articles/2024-06-03/biden-takes-a-big-swing-at-hostage-for-truce-deal-puts-onus-on-israeli-hamas-officials-to-step-up", "title": "Biden Takes a Big Swing at Hostage-For-Truce Deal, Puts Onus on Israeli, Hamas Officials to Step Up", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- President Joe Biden is looking past resistance from key Israeli officials as he presses Israel and Hamas to agree to a three-phase agreement that could immediately bring home dozens of Israeli hostages, free Palestinian prisoners and perhaps even lead to an endgame in the nearly eight-month-old Gaza war.\n\nBiden's big swing -- during a tough reelection battle -- could also demonstrate to a significant slice of his political base demoralized by his handling of the conflict that he's doing his part to end the war that has killed more than 36,000 Palestinians and left hundreds of thousands struggling to meet basic needs.\n\nWhite House officials on Monday said Biden's decision to make public what it describes as an Israeli proposal -- just one day after it was delivered to Hamas -- was driven by a desire to put Hamas on the spot. The move diverged from the U.S. administration's position throughout the conflict to allow the Israelis to speak for themselves about hostage negotiations.\n\n\"The president felt that where we are in this war, where we are in the negotiations to get the hostages out, that it was time for a different approach and a time to make the proposal public, to try to energize the process here and catalyze a different outcome,\" White House national security spokesman John Kirby said.\n\nAlmost immediately after Biden detailed the proposal -- which includes a cease-fire and phased Israeli troop withdrawal from Gaza if Hamas releases all hostages -- Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office said it would continue its war until Hamas was destroyed.\n\nNETANYAHU FACING PRESSURE FROM FAR-RIGHT\n\nNetanyahu's political survival depends on a far-right coalition that is adamant about eradicating Hamas. He sowed further doubt about proposal's viability Monday when he told an Israeli parliament committee that there are certain \"gaps\" in how Biden laid out the proposal. The prime minister said Israelis \"reserve the right to return to war.\"\n\nKirby played down differences between Biden and Netanyahu and underscored that the proposal was an Israeli one. He added that Biden agrees with Israelis that Hamas should not govern postwar Gaza nor does he \"expect that Israel should have to live next door to that kind of a terrorist threat.\"\n\n\"This wasn't about jamming the prime minister, the war cabinet,\" Kirby said. \"This was about laying bare for the public to see how well and how faithfully and how assertively the Israelis came up with a new proposal. It shows how much they really want to get this done.\"\n\nBut even if Hamas agreed to terms, it would require Netanyahu to make some difficult political calculations. Two leading members of his far-right coalition -- National Security Minister Itamar Ben-Gvir and Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich -- have threatened to leave Netanyahu's government if he signs off on the proposal. That would cause the coalition to collapse.\n\nSmotrich said Monday that agreeing to a cease-fire would amount to a humiliation of Israel and a surrender. Increased military pressure, he said, is \"the only language understood in the Middle East.\"\n\nNetanyahu has also faced pressure from families of hostages -- officials say about 80 people captured by militants i n the Oct. 7 attack are still alive and Hamas is holding the bodies of 43 others -- to reach an agreement to free their loved ones. Opposition leader Yair Lapid, however, vowed over the weekend to provide a political safety net to Netanyahu, ensuring his government would not fall over the deal.\n\nOPTIMISM DESPITE HEADWINDS\n\nEven as the proposal faces stiff headwinds, the Biden administration said it was cautiously optimistic that a deal could be reached.\n\nWhite House national security adviser Jake Sullivan urged world leaders to rally behind the proposal.\n\n\"They need to train their eyes on Hamas this week and say it's time to come to the table to do this deal,\" Sullivan said in an appearance at the U.S. Global Leadership Conference in Washington.\n\nTo that end, Biden on Monday spoke with Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani of Qatar, a key Hamas interlocutor, and said it was \"the best possible opportunity for an agreement,\" the White House said.\n\nSullivan, meanwhile, spoke to his Turkish counterpart, Akif Cagatay Kilic, about Turkey using its influence with Hamas to get them to accept the proposal. Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has defended Hamas and hosted the group's political leader, Ismail Haniyeh, for talks in April.\n\nGroup of Seven leaders on Monday also endorsed the deal.\n\n\"We call on Hamas to accept this deal, that Israel is ready to move forward with, and we urge countries with influence over Hamas to help ensure that it does so,\" the G7 leaders said in a statement.\n\nEVEN GETTING TO PHASE ONE IS A CHALLENGE\n\nBiden acknowledged last week that getting beyond the first phase of the proposal would be difficult.\n\nThe first phase would last for six weeks and would include a cease-fire, a withdrawal of Israeli forces from all densely populated areas of Gaza and the release of a number of hostages, including women, the elderly and the wounded, in exchange for the release of hundreds of Palestinian prisoners.\n\nThe Israelis, under the proposal, would also allow 600 humanitarian aid trucks into Gaza each day during the first phase. The second phase would include the release of all remaining living hostages, including male soldiers, and Israeli forces would withdraw from Gaza.\n\nHamas is likely to make enormous demands about which Palestinian prisoners will be released and call on Israel to assure that it won't continue to target top Hamas leaders.\n\nAaron David Miller, a former U.S. Middle East peace negotiator, said even getting to phase one -- and the six-week pause in fighting -- would bring about a \"downshift in the escalation of the military campaign, fewer people dying.\"\n\n\"I'm not sure they can expect much more,\" said Miller, now a senior fellow at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. \"Negotiations work in the end only if the parties feel sufficient pain accompanied by the prospects of gain, and that generates urgency. The only party that is in a hurry here is the Biden administration.\"\n\nIndeed, Israeli officials view the conflict on a far longer timeline.\n\nJust last week, Israeli national security adviser Tzachi Hanegbi said he expected the war to drag on for another seven months, in order to destroy the military and governing capabilities of Hamas and the smaller Islamic Jihad militant group.\n\nBut with Election Day in the U.S. now just over five months away, Biden faces tightening pressure to more quickly resolve the Mideast conflict that's left him bleeding support.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved.
